DOC.HEAD: American, Deaf Thais Produce Pioneering Dictionary
DOC.TEXT: Deaf Thais aided by an American have produced what they say is the first real dictionary for the deaf in the developing world. They hope it will help end discrimination against the handicapped in Thailand. The 1,500-page dictionary took eight years to complete and involved setting down 3,500 signs in pictoral form, according to editor-in-chief Owen Wrigley, 37, of Manhattan, Kan. The dictionary is to be officially released shortly. ``We hope it will provide not only a useful tool for the deaf but that the dictionary is offered as proof that the Thais have a distinctive national sign language,'' Wrigley said in an interview. Wrigley said it is hoped such recognition would help the cause of the deaf, who now are barred from government service and from the Buddhist monkhood. They cannot legally acquire driving licenses and some Thais want them to lose the right to vote on grounds the deaf are not literate. It is conservatively estimated that 100,000 Thais are deaf. That figure does not incloude those who lose their hearing in old age. Most are poor manual laborers, seamstresses and street vendors. Wrigley estimates that at most 5 percent of deaf children are able to attend schools. The only deaf college graduate known in Thailand is a woman who lost her hearing as a teen-ager and was able to complete a teacher's training college course. A Disabled Persons Act aimed at giving the handicapped a better deal has languished in Parliament for years. Wrigley said he became involved in helping the deaf shortly after arriving in Thailand in 1981 with the U.S.-based International Human Assistance Program. The United Nations had declared that year the Year of the Disabled Person. Working with the National Association of the Deaf in Thailand, Wrigley obtained funds for the project from the U.S. government, United Nations, Canada, Australia and local donors. The research team included deaf people. One, a dynamic young woman named Manfa Suwanarat, died before the dictionary was completed after receiving questionable treatment for a medical ailment. The team interviewed the deaf throughout Thailand, taking notes and photographing the signs they used to communicate. The dictionary graphically depicts the signs and explains them in written form in Thai and English. A few of the signs were drawn from abroad, particularly American sign language, but by far the largest majority have their roots in Thailand and its culture. To communicate ``Thailand,'' in sign language, the forefinger is extended and crooked to resemble an elephant's trunk. The elephant features prominently in Thai history and culture. Wrigley said dictionaries for the deaf are a recent development. The first appeared in the United States in 1965. Only a few other nations in the West have produced or are working on them. There are no full-fledged dictionaries for the deaf known to exist in the developing world. Wrigley notes that many people believe the deaf can communicate easily through an international sign language. One such does exist - developed in Italy in the 1960s and called Gestuno - but Wrigley says it has about as much popularity and relevance as the international spoken language Esperanto.

DOC.HEAD: Australian Disaster Zone Declared as Cyclone Weakens
DOC.TEXT: The northern coast region of Queensland was declared a disaster zone today because of devastation wrought by Cyclone Joy, now weakened off the northeastern coast. State disaster relief officials said damage estimates were put at more than $30 million. After three days of battering coast communities with high winds and rainfall associated with the storm, the cyclone slowly dissipated as it moved southeast down the coast. Officials said the tourist town of Cairns sustained more than $7.5 million in damage. Banana growers also suffered heavily. Some lost half their crop. Power was cut in Cairns, roofs of houses were torn off, highways were flooded and the international airport was closed for two days. Some tourists had to spend Christmas Day in the airport compound or in makeshift tents. As a disaster zone, the northern coast region is eligible for state funds to help in the cleanup. At its strongest, Cyclone Joy packed winds of 145 mph at its center. By today, the winds had dropped by nearly half and the Brisbane Weather Office said the storm was no longer a major threat to coast communities.

DOC.TEXT: Foy David Kohler, a career diplomat and the U.S. ambassador to Moscow during the height of the Cold War, died Sunday at age 82. Kohler died at Jupiter Hospital after a long illness. The hospital released no details on the cause of death. Kohler was ambassador to the Soviet Union from August 1962 to November 1966. He was considered a member of the realist school of international politics, which emphasized the importance of military, economic and political power in world affairs. Kohler first went to Moscow in January 1947 as first secretary of the U.S. Embassy. He was there when Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev and then-Vice President Richard Nixon toured a model American kitchen during a 1959 American exposition in Moscow. Khrushchev became angry, and the ``kitchen debate'' between him and Nixon drew international attention. President John F. Kennedy tapped the Russian-speaking diplomat to become ambassador to the Soviet Union in 1962. Shortly after he arrived in Moscow, the Cuban missile crisis erupted and brought the world to the brink of war. Kohler retired in 1967, then spent almost 11 years as a professor at the University of Miami's graduate center for Advanced International Studies.

Donald Eugene Walters, a former president of Montclair State College, died Sunday of brain cancer at age 56. He died at his home in Cape Cod, Mass. Walters was executive director of the Illinois Board of Governors, a body that runs several Illinois state campuses, from 1975 to 1984. Before that he been with the Massachusetts State College System. Walters served as president of Montclair from 1984 to 1988, when he retired because of illness.

Robert Lee Bonaparte, a retired vice president of Boise Cascade Corp., died Saturday of heart failure at age 67. He died at his home. A newsprint and marketing specialist, Bonaparte worked for Boise Cascade for about 25 years until his retirement as a vice president in 1987. At the time of his death, he was a senior adviser for the company. In 1965, Bonaparte co-founded Schramsberg Vineyards in California's Napa Valley.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Crisis: Economic Stranglehold for Developing Nations
With PM-Gulf-Rich Nations, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Eds: Moved in advance Dec. 17 as b0124.

The world's poor nations have been dealt a staggering economic blow by Saddam Hussein's occupation of Kuwait and the higher oil prices it created. Countries struggling to climb out of poverty are having to cope with losses in the billions of dollars. Rising prices of gasoline and other petroleum products have affected every sector of their economies. Inflation abounds, trade has suffered and foreign exchange reserves are shrinking. ``It's a big blow,'' said Gene Tidrick, a World Bank economist in New Delhi. ``The big problem is uncertainty. No one knows for how long this will last.'' Many developing nations find the U.N. embargo of trade with Iraq and occupid Kuwait has affected their exports. The International Monetary Fund estimates the crisis cost African nations $2 billion in 1990. India, Pakistan, Bangladesh and Sri Lanka stand to lose a total of more than $2.5 billion in 1990. All four import oil, had strong trade links with Iraq and Kuwait and received remittances from thousands of citizens working in the two nations. Economists in New Delhi project a loss of more than $2.5 billion for India alone if the crisis continues until March. Brazil's oil bill has risen $1.2 billion. Philippine government efforts to cope with the problem prompted demonstrations against President Corazon Aquino. Here is a review of some developing countries and how they are affected: BANGLADESH - A continuing crisis in the gulf would cost more than $500 million a year: $150 million in lost remittances from workers, $222 million in higher oil prices and $150 million in lost exports and tax revenue, mostly from tea and jute sales. BRAZIL - The oil bill has doubled to $600 million a month, inflation is rising and many Brazilian companies with projects in Iraq had to abandon them. CHILE - About $200 million has been added to the 1990 oil bill and an oil stabilization fund has been established, primarily with money from an increase in the price of copper, Chile's main export. EGYPT - Lost revenues totaled $6.7 billion because of a decline in the tourist industry, reduced income from the Suez Canal and an end to remittances from 400,000 Egyptians working in Iraq and Kuwait. The United States and Persian Gulf nations wrote off Egyptian debts of $13.7 billion, however, and the rise in oil prices helped Egypt, an oil exporter. HUNGARY - Total losses are about $200 million, officials say, including $145 million Iraq owes Hungary and $55 million in canceled contracts. Not included is $120 million in higher prices for oil, most of which comes from the Soviet Union. INDIA - Economists say the cost will reach $2.72 billion by the end of the fiscal year in March, including $2.3 billion in increased oil imports, $220 million in lost remittances from workers and $167 million in lost exports. Foreign exchange reserves fell to less than $2 billion in November. The government has increased gasoline prices 25 percent and is trying to get a loan from the International Monetary Fund. KENYA - Fuel prices have risen 30 percent. Vice President George Saitoti asked Kenyans to limit driving and stop buying imported goods. PAKISTAN - All Pakistan's refined oil products came from Kuwait. Finance Minister Sartaj Aziz said the crisis is costing $33 million a month and analysts say annual inflation could reach 20 percent. About $2 billion has been added to the foreign debt of $15.5 billion. PHILIPPINES - Filipinos held street protests in response to Mrs. Aquino's efforts to raise the prices of petroleum products by an average 45 percent. She later rolled back some increases. The Philippines has lost remittances from 30,000 citizens who returned from jobs in Iraq and Kuwait. SRI LANKA - Officials put the cost for 1990 at $130 million and say the annual inflation rate might surpass 20 percent. Many of the 90,000 Sri Lankans working in the gulf region have returned home and losses of remittances are expected to reach $53 million. Higher oil prices will raise the energy bill by $87 million. ZAMBIA - Fuel costs have more than doubled, causing the prices of transportation, food and other necessities to soar. ZIMBABWE - Energy cost about $400 million in 1990, nearly double the previous figure. President Robert Mugabe recommended that developing nations pool energy resources and technology to blunt the impact.

DOC.HEAD: Freed Hostages and Families Enjoy Christmas They Thought They'd Miss
DOC.TEXT: Bonnie Anderton was going to spend Christmas Day in the nation's capital campaigning for the release of Iraq's hostages - including her husband. She and 11-year-old daughter Jennifer had a petition to deliver to the Iraqi Embassy. ``It was the nicest wasted effort I've ever made,'' said Mrs. Anderton, whose husband, Richard, was among holdouts at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait allowed to leave in time for the holidays. Just two weeks ago, she and families around the nation wondered whether they'd ever see their captive loved ones again. Since Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, they'd had mostly bad news - or none at all. ``He didn't think he'd be home and we didn't think he'd be home,'' Mrs. Anderton, 40, said Monday from Larkspur, Colo. ``That's why it's so special just to be together.'' They're thankful at how things worked out for them, especially compared with the nearly 300,000 U.S. servicemen and women in the Persian Gulf and their families. Despite the Andertons' good fortune, it's still a somber holiday season with the United States on the brink of war. ``I'm extremely glad my husband isn't sitting on the 50-yard line, but there's still a tremendous problem to be solved,'' Mrs. Anderton said. ``It's far from over.'' Pete Dooley never thought he'd be out in time to sip champagne and sit around the Christmas tree opening gifts at home in Kentucky. In a twinkling, he went from hiding in Iraqi-occupied Kuwait to freedom and the loving arms of relatives who had prepared for the worst. ``We were looking for the long haul,'' his mother, Kitty Dooley, said Monday from Hopkinsville, Ky. ``We didn't dream we'd have him with us ... that we'd be calling out with joy.'' Dooley, 40, was among hundreds of Americans freed earlier this month by Saddam Hussein. ``I was artfully eluding capture. That was the goal of my days. It was lonely ... tense, nervous,'' said Dooley, who managed restaurants for a Kuwaiti company. ``Two weeks ago, I certainly had no plans to be here, to be home for Christmas. ``Freedom is what's important. Even to take out the trash is a treat.'' The Rev. Edwin Davis will say a special grace for his son-in-law before the traditional holiday supper. His daughter's husband, like many Kuwaitis married to Americans, stayed behind to defend his country and relatives. ``We're happy that Martha and the two grandchildren are back home safely with us, but we're still praying for Mike,'' Davis said from Koran, La. ``We just hope he can get out of there before there's a war. We're wondering about a war.'' Global worries aside, freed hostages want to spend the time trying to relax and enjoy a respite from tensions that have dominated recent months. ``You can't help but think about the politics and the troops over there,'' said Guy Seago, an oil worker who was used as a so-called human shield. ``But for me the focus this Christmas is on faith,'' the father of six said from Johnson City, Tenn. ``It's on faith and thanks and quiet time with the family.'' James E. Carroll's wife and seven children had a Christmas tree waiting when he arrived home in Augusta, Ga. ``It's just a special Christmas ... of being thankful to the Lord,'' said Carroll, a pediatrician who also holed up at the U.S. Embassy in Kuwait. Another family had not planned to have Christmas this year. ``We weren't going to celebrate,'' said Margaret Williams of Germantown, Tenn., whose son and daughter-in-law were held by Iraqi troops. And now the holiday has become a little anticlimactic. ``Our Christmas already came,'' Mrs. Williams said. ``It came when we saw them home and safe. It came when they were free and back here with us.''

DOC.HEAD: Season of Giving: Charities Help Make Christmas Merrier for Poor
LaserPhoto NY4
DOC.TEXT: Single mother Valerie Bodon wanted to shower her four sons with gifts and cook a scrumptious Christmas feast today - but there was no money. Luckily, she wasn't too proud to ask for help. For Mrs. Bodon, who tries to make ends meet with food stamps and a $405 monthly government check, the help came from a small Indianapolis group that prefers to remain anonymous. Delivered to her door last week were about 30 wrapped gifts, four stockings stuffed with candy, fruit and other treats, a miniature, decorated Christmas tree and two gift certificates from a supermarket and discount shoe store. Mrs. Bodon has been studying accounting at Butler University so she can get a better job. She was divorced three years ago while working as an accounting clerk, a job that did not pay enough to support the family. Knowing she had virtually nothing to give her boys for Christmas, she went to one of the 14 Community Centers of Indianapolis in November to ask for help. The non-profit agency, which provided Christmas assistance to more than 3,500 families last year, brings together people who want to help with those who need it, spokesman Ward Beckham said. ``She's trying to go to school, trying to raise a family, trying to keep her budget balanced,'' said Mike Waddell, her counselor at one of the centers. ``She impressed me as somebody who's going to be a real success when she starts working.'' Many other families are in similar circumstances. Most are headed by single mothers trying to get by on welfare. Others are elderly people on Social Security. The Community Centers of Indianapolis help families when they are behind on their rent or utility bills or when the cupboards are empty. At Christmas, the centers work with stores and groups such as Kmart, the Fire Department, Marine reservists, supermarkets, service clubs and the gas company, which donate money, food or toys, Beckham said. Affluent churches funnel help through the community centers or churches that serve the poor. Yet the churches and agencies can help only those who ask for it. Some children will have empty stockings because their parents are either too proud, embarrassed or drug-addicted to seek help, officials say. ``A lot of children don't get the Christmas they want. A few don't get the Christmas they need,'' said Cindy Clements, executive director of Christamore House, another of the centers. With the extra help from her anonymous benefactors, Mrs. Bodon will be able to give her children more than they could have expected. ``I'm just happy that somebody is doing this for me,'' she said. ``As long as the tree isn't bare on Christmas, then they'll be satisfied.''

DOC.HEAD: Police: Arson Destroys Homeowner's Nativity Scene for 2nd Straight Year
DOC.TEXT: For the second year in a row, a Christmas firebug torched a front-lawn Nativity scene, police said. After the elaborate Christmas display the Scaringi family of Monsey puts up every year was set ablaze last Decemeber, the family installed an alarm system to deter arsonists. The alarm went off at about 1:30 a.m. Monday, but the damage was done. The family woke up to see the figures in the Nativity scene burning. The fire was doused by firefighters and police, but the Christmas display was destroyed. Ramapo Police Lt. Guy Estead said the fire was intentionally set. No arrests were made. There was no damage to the home and no injuries. Anthony Scaringi is offering a $3,000 reward to help catch the culprit.

DOC.HEAD: Cambodia Again Faces Serious Food Shortage
DOC.TEXT: Cambodia, a nation ravaged by war and revolution for the past 20 years, is again facing severe food shortages because of increased fighting, drought and floods, United Nations officials say. Some refugees who say they cannot grow rice are among the roughly 20,000 Cambodians who fled west to guerrilla-controlled camps in Thailand this year. Thousands of others went east to areas under government control. Government officials in Phnom Penh expect that Cambodia's 8 million people will be shot about 100,000 tons of rice in 1991, or three times the official deficit for this year, Scott Leiper of the U.N. World Food Program told donor countries at a Dec. 18 meeting. ``The situation is causing concern,'' said S.A.M.S. Kibria, the U.N. secretary-general's special representative for Cambodian aid programs. ``From all indications the food situation had improved over the last couple of years,'' he said in an interview Monday. ``This year, because of the fighting, a lot of the land was left uncultivated. Secondly, the rainfall both in terms of quantity and timing was not right.'' Another major factor, he said, was that the Soviets have stopped providing fertilizer as a result of their general disengagement from Cambodia. Cambodia had been getting about 50,000 tons of fertilizer annually, but only a fifth of that amount was available for the 1990 wet season crop, Leiper said. The Vietnamese-installed government in Phnom Penh is battling three guerrilla groups, and fighting has spread since the Vietnamese troop pullout that began in September 1989. Each year, combat intensifies during the dry season that has just begun. The U.N. Security Council has drawn up a peace plan to end the civil war in Cambodia, but representatives of the warring factions failed during talks in Paris last weekend to agree on all parts of the plan. Millions died in Cambodia in the 1970-75 civil war, the 1975-78 bloody rule of the communist Khmer Rouge, and in the fighting since late 1978 when invading Vietnamese troops drove the Khmer Rouge into the jungles. Western isolation of the communist Phnom Penh government has kept the country impoverished. Leiper, head of the World Food Program's Phnom Penh office, told the donor countries that the shortages are expected to hit hardest in southwestern Kampot and Kompongspeu provinces, which have suffered ``alarming'' food shortages due to drought the past two years. They are expected to face a combined food deficit of 44,000 tons of rice in 1991 - about 40 percent of the total nationwide deficit. Leiper said prolonged drought in many areas of the central and southeastern provinces has reduced the area planted, and flooding in the west and the fighting has also reduced cultivation. Cambodia's official SPK news agency recently said drought and floods had destroyed more than half the cultivated area in the central province of Kompong Thom. It said the average yield was expected to drop by a third compared to last year in the northwestern province of Battambang, a main agricultural region, due to bad weather and guerilla harassment. Leiper also requested aid for the 130,000 people, many living in dire conditions, who have been displaced in government-held territory this past year. Getting them food, he said, has been hampered by shortages of trucks and fuel, and the country's battered infrastructure. International aid officials say about 90 percent of these people had fled the fighting in the western provinces of Battambang and Banteay Meanchey. The World Food Program moved cautiously in appealing for aid because some of the other refugees, in Kompongspeu and Kompong Chhnang provinces, said the government had moved them out of their villages because of guerrilla infiltration. At the donor meeting, Sweden pledged $6.6 million for aid inside Cambodia. The United States pledged $10 million and the European Community $6 million to help about 300,000 refugees in Thai border camps controlled by the guerrillas.

DOC.HEAD: Santa, Reindeer Alight on Hospital Ship in Persian Gulf
With PM-World Xmas Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Santa appeared in the Persian Gulf on Christmas Eve, alighting aboard this hospital ship with a full complement of reindeer. It was not completely a surprise visit. Fifteen minutes beforehand, the public address system crackled to life to announce that AWACS surveillance planes high overhead were reporting a ``single unidentified aircraft'' closing in on the ship. The craft was moving too slowly to be intercepted by Navy F-15 fighter jets, later announcements said. Finally came the report it was ``a sleigh pulled by deer and driven by an old man.'' The jingle of bells on the address system heralded its arrival. Santa's real identity was the ship's air boss, Cmdr. Stanley Schmidt. He handed out packages addressed to ``any service member.'' Nurses and corpsmen perched on his lap as he sat on a cargo dolly decorated like a sleigh. Pulling the dolly were seven men and women wearing cardboard reindeer antlers stuck high over their ears. Lead reindeer Rudolph - actually Cmdr. Dan Barrett, 44, of Flint, Mich., the ship's lawyer - had a bulbous red nose. The singalong right after the visit included such highlights as ``Rashid The Red Nosed Camel'' and ``Two Dinars,'' an ode to the high fares of Bahrain taxi drivers. In other Christmas events, the movie ``Miracle on 34th Street'' was playing in O Lounge. The Catholic chaplain, The Rev. Richard Mattie, 58, scheduled a Midnight Mass and both he and Protestant chaplain Lt. Cmdr. Doug Weadick, 40, planned an ecumenical service. Both are from Hornell, N.Y. Weadick said his Christmas message would concentrate on ``being able to relinquish your life to the powers that be ... on having to sacrifice our individualism for the common good.'' Mattie said he planned to talk about ``the price we have to pay to preserve peace.'' The only Christmas religious service being held in public for Operation Desert Shield was on the Mercy. Like other Navy ships in international waters, it is not subject to Saudi Arabian law which bans all religions except Islam. The 1,000-bed hospital is decorated throughout with trees, cards, baubles and paintings sent by schoolchildren from the United States. There are 35 patients on board, including one brought on Sunday from an auto accident in the United Arab Emirates in which two seaman died. He was in stable condition in intensive care after being in surgery all night. The ship is back at sea after an 18-day port call that included being fitted with a chemical alarm system. Cmdr. Debra Wear, the psychiatrist aboard the floating hospital, said there had been some depression among the people she had seen but not as much as one would expect. ``It's missing a son's first steps, everything's a little more poignant and felt more acutely over the holidays. But it's more people having the blues, it's not significant depression.''

DOC.HEAD: Christmas Sales Still Sluggish Despite 11th-Hour Rush
DOC.TEXT: When all the receipts are tallied, Christmas sales are likely to be unchanged or barely above last year, a poor season for retailers who couldn't overcome consumer worries over the economy and Middle East. Shopping traffic was slow at many stores and malls this season and consumers who did shop bought selectively. High-profile retailing companies around the country complained Monday their sales were a disappointment. Sales that are unchanged or barely higher are considered poor, because after the rate of inflation is subtracted, a store's business may be down from year-earlier levels. Consumer prices rose 6.4 percent through the first 11 months of this year, meaning many stores' modest gains were wiped out. ``It has not been a disaster, but it has been a pretty flat season,'' said Suzanne McMillan, senior vice president for marketing at Saks Fifth Avenue. ``It's not going to be anything that's going to excite anybody,'' said Kenneth Macke, chairman of Dayton Hudson Corp. The company's sales will be unchanged or perhaps 1 percent higher than last year, Macke said. Many retailers increased or moved up price reductions in the last few weeks in an effort to draw more shoppers. Nationwide chains reported their worst results came in the Northeast, where the recesssion has hit particularly hard. The first inkling of real trouble among retailers came back in August as sales of clothing, furniture, toys and appliances stalled in the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Sales for most retailers failed to ick up in the early fall, a time when business normally accelerates. When the Christmas season kicked off, sales remained slow although they picked up some steam during the last week. In many areas, weather extremes also hampered holiday sales. Younkers Inc., a Des Moines-based chain of 34 Midwestern department stores, said its December sales, which rose between 2 percent and 3 percent, would have been higher if not for heavy snows and frigid temperatures. ``We did very well considering the weather,'' said Younkers president W. Thomas Gould. Younkers' sales were 2 percent to 3 percent higher than last year, a better year than most retailers, especially those with higher-priced items. In parts of the country where temperatures have been in the 50s and 60s for much of December, the warm weather dealt a blow to winter clothing sales. Sears, Roebuck and Co., the nation's largest retailer, was among the stores that moved up apparel clearance sales because the merchandise was not moving. Results at Dayton Hudson, whose stores range from upscale department stores to the Target discount chain, reflected the fact that consumers were ``trading down,'' or buying cheaper gifts. What shoppers bought also reflected the difficult season. Dayton Hudson had more success with Levi's jeans than with designer jeans, and sweatshirts and sweatpants were among the most popular items, Macke said. ``It was a very functional Christmas,'' he said. Macke said the poor Christmas does not bode well for the first half of 1991. ``If Santa Claus and Christmas can't bring people into the stores, why are they going to be in in January and February?'' he asked.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Refuses to Order Feeding of Dying Woman
DOC.TEXT: For the seventh time, a court refused to order a hospital to resume feeding Nancy Cruzan, the severely brain-injured woman whose family won her right to die. Meanwhile on Christmas Eve, eight anti-euthanasia demonstrators huddled -without their tent - outside the building where she lay dying. Protesters have maintained a round-the-clock vigil since Ms. Cruzan's feeding tube was removed Dec. 14. The court decision Monday came in response to a request by the Rev. Patrick J. Mahoney of Boca Raton, Fla., who argued the state was violating Ms. Cruzan's rights by not ordering her to be fed. The 8th U.S. Circuit Court of Appeals issued a one-page order that said Mahoney had no standing in the case. Mahoney said he would take his case to the U.S. Supreme Court. The U.S. District Court for Western Missouri had earlier dismissed Mahoney's suit. Ms. Cruzan has been in a persistent vegetative state since an auto crash in early 1983. Doctors give her n chance of recovery. She remained in deteriorating condition today. Also Monday, authorities ordered demonstrators outside the Missouri Rehabilitation Center to remove a tent they had erected. When protesters refused, hospital employees took it down. The demonstrators had been using a torch in the tent to combat the bone-chilling weather. The arrangement was considered a fire hazard and once temperatures warmed into the 20s Monday, hospital officials order it removed, hospital director Don Lamkins said. In a landmark ruling, the U.S. Supreme Court said earlier this year Missouri could require ``clear and convincing'' evidence that a person in Ms. Cruzan's condition would want to die. Jasper County Judge Charles Teel then heard testimony from friends who said Ms. Cruzan would want to die and ruled her parents could have the feeding tube removed. The latest appeals court ruling was the seventh time a court had refused to order feeding of Ms. Cruzan resumed. Mahoney's motion said the state was violating Ms. Cruzan's rights and argued the hearing Teel held was improper because witnesses who testified were not cross-examined and there were no witnesses who said Ms. Cruzan should be kept alive. Mahoney also argued that the state had erred by not appealing Teel's order. The clergyman filed his action under a legal concept called ``next of friend,'' describing it as a strategy to be used when no one else was protecting the rights of a person. In taking the case to the U.S. Supreme Court, Mahoney said he would cite testimony from the former chaplain at the hospital who said Ms. Cruzan had a noticeable reaction when he told her she was going to die. Unlike comatose patients, Ms. Cruzan opens her eyes and changes her facial expressions, but doctors testified her lack of consciousness was irreversible and she had no awareness and could not feel pain. Mahoney is director of the Center for Christian Activities, a right-to-life group associated with the anti-abortion group Operation Rescue.

DOC.HEAD: New Airport to Include `Reflection Room'
DOC.TEXT: Weary travelers seeking to escape the stress - and fear - of flying will find sanctuary at Greater Pittsburgh International Airport's new terminal. Architect Tasso Katselas was asked to include the room in his design for the $625 million terminal, scheduled to open in late 1992. ``We want to keep it as quiet as possible. It will be a large, dramatic room,'' Katselas said. The room will provide airline passengers with ``an opportunity to step out of things for a moment, reorient yourself, then jump back in the fray,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: American Alleges Pilots Are Staging a Sickout
DOC.TEXT: American Airlines accused its pilots of staging a sickout during one of the busiest travel times of the year to protest stalled contract talks. American, based in Forth Worth, said the number of pilots calling in sick over the weekend before Christmas soared to record numbers. The absentee rate was almost 70 percent higher than normal, airline officials said. Union officials denied any organized protest was occurring but conceded that disgruntled employees could be acting on their own. American management and the Allied Pilots Association have been negotiating a contract for 14 months but have made little headway. ``It's all an attempt to compel the company to agree to terms that the pilots would like us to on the contract,'' said Robert W. Baker, American executive vice president for operations. Baker said 529 of American's 9,000 pilots were on sick leave Monday. About 500 pilots had called in sick over the weekend. The pilot absentee rate is about 250 normally and 300 during Christmas holidays, American spokesman Marty Heires said. ``We have to assume there's some union activity here,'' Heires said. ``Now, I don't know whether this was an organized effort or whether some pilots are taking it upon themselves to do this. ``All we're seeing is the end result. We've had an approximate 67 percent increase in the number of pilots calling in sick,'' he said. Union officials denied a concerted effort is behind the higher absentee rate. ``I know there's nothing going on in terms of any grassroots operation or any other type of operation to call in sick or not being available,'' AA executive director Scott Peterson said. Baker said the absentee rate for flight attendants was average. The apparent pilot sickout, coupled with bad weather, a high volume of holiday traffic and the airline's loss of 230 pilots to Operation Desert Shield led to an unusually high number of flight cancellations over the weekend, Heires said. American canceled 74 flights, or one in every 11 flights, into and out of its hub at Dallas-Fort Worth International Airport during Sunday's holiday crunch. A sickout would be illegal under the Railway Labor Act, which also covers airlines. Both management and labor traded contract proposals in the past month but remain far apart. Negotiations resume Jan. 7 in Washington under the auspices of federal mediators. Under the Railway Labor Act, the existing contract will remain in force until a federal mediator declares an impasse. After a 30-day cooling off period, the carrier may impose new terms on the pilots and the union can strike. The union has been urging members to be diligent about seeking sick leave when ill and not to answer their phones if they don't want to work on their days off. ``Although the company may be disappointed in that, there's nothing illegal about it,'' said APA spokesman Tom Hunt. ``What's the reason for that? I think it's low morale. There's no question the pilots at American Airlines are extremely disgruntled with the company, with management.''

DOC.HEAD: Freeze Devastates California Orange Crop, Damages Others
DOC.TEXT: The worst freeze since 1937 devastated California's navel orange crop, sending growers into Christmas with little hope of salvaging the season's harvest. ``This is way worse than I've ever seen,'' Bakersfield-area grower John Slikker Jr. said Monday. ``Yesterday, we cut these oranges in half. ... It was just like cutting through a Popsicle.'' The weekend Arctic blast also damaged nursery plants, lemons and avocados and destroyed most early Southern California strawberries, agriculture officials said. Crop damage was put in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Cliff Holland of California Citrus Mutual, a growers organization, admitted the string of freezing nights probably destroyed the state's 1990-91 navel orange harvest. ``It will take some time to assess damage, but it looks bleak at this point,'' he said. About 80 percent of the 1990-91 crop, estimated at between 60 million cartons and 80 million cartons, remained on the trees, Holland said. Most of California's navel oranges are sold on the fresh market. Florida oranges, in contrast, are used mostly for juice and juice concentrate; those that sustain frost damage can sometimes be salvaged for juice processing. The Sunkist Growers Inc. cooperative said early estimates indicated that at least half the citrus crop sustained frost damage, spokeswoman Claire Peters said. She added that growers hope to salvage some for juice. ``There will be fewer fruit and what there is will cost more,'' Peters said. Inmporters of Chilean fruit, like Los Angeles-based David Oppenheimer & Co., expected demand for foreign fruit to increase as markets scramble to make up for local losses. It was ``freeze-of-the-century stuff,'' said Dave Carman of the National Weather Service. ``This is probably the second-coldest freeze of the century. We are dealing with extreme record cold.'' Since Friday, temperatures throughout the San Joaquin Valley citrus region had dipped to 20 degrees and below and were forecast to drop into the teens early today. It was the worst freeze since 1937, officials said. Navel oranges begin to show damage if temperatures fall to 25 or 26 degrees and stay at that level or below for at least four hours, Holland said. ``Basically, I have written off the crop that is on the tree,'' said Chris Caviglia, a Tulare County grower. ``What I'm concerned about now is the crop for next year. I could very well lose it as well if the trees aren't protected.'' The navels were more vulnerable than normal this season because they were about two weeks late in maturing, leaving the rinds too thin to ward off much cold. California navels are harvested between November and June. The 1989 navel orange crop was valued at $248 million, compared to $1.29 billion in Florida orange production that year. Losses in Tulare County, which produces most of the state's navel oranges, were expected to be about $200 million, said county Agriculture Commissioner Lenord Craft. State officials said most strawberries were lost but provided no dollar figure for the damage. In Ventura County, losses to lemons, avocados and nursery stocks, or nonfood-bearing plants, totaled at least $100 million, said Jim Fulmer, deputy agricultural commissioner. About one-fifth of the state's avocados, which account for 90 percent of national consumption, were lost, said Mark Affleck, president of the California Avocado Commission. The extent of damage to vegetable fields in the Sacramento and San Joaquin valleys wasn't known, but some farmers reported losses. Joe P. Prandini, general manager of Betteravia Farms Co., said he lost about 35 percent of the cauliflower grown on his 4,000-acre farm. Holland said California growers have been fortunate in avoiding devastating freezes in the past. Some have saved for a bad year, but others will be hurt. ``I talk to growers who try to keep a minimum of one year's farming costs in the bank, but we also have people in the industry with tremendous debt on groves,'' he said. ``There are going to be some hard times.''

DOC.HEAD: Parolees Charged With Capital Homicide In Double Slaying Laugh in Court
DOC.TEXT: Two recent parolees accused of killing a grandmother and her daughter, and shooting the younger woman's husband in the face before kidnapping two of their daughters joked with each other in court during their arraignment on murder charges. Von Lester Taylor, 25, and Edward Steven Deli, 21, were formally charged Monday with two counts each of first-degree murder, a capital offense in Utah, attempted murder, arson, two counts of kidnapping and robbery. The defendants, parolees who walked away from a halfway house while purportedly out looking for jobs, were in jovial spirits at their arraignment, whispering to each other and sharing a few laughs. They disputed claims that a police officer fired just two shots at them before they surrendered. They said he fired at least a dozen times. Taylor and Deli are accused in the Saturday shooting deaths of Beth Harmon Tidwell Potts, mid-70s, of Murray, and her daughter, Kay Tidwell Tiede, 51, of Humble, Texas. The two women were found dead at the family cabin east of Oakley. Mrs. Tiede's husband, Rolf, 51, was shot in the face and taken by helicopter to the University of Utah Medical Center in Salt Lake City, where he was released Monday, the hospital said. The victims surprised their attackers during a burglary, police said. The two men also were accused of setting the cabin on fire and abducting two of the Tiedes daughters, Linae, 20, and Tricia, 16, before fleeing with them in the family's car. The Summit County sheriff's office was alerted by a caller who reported hearing shots and seeing two men fleeing with two young women. With police giving chase, they drove at speeds above 100 mph before losing control of the car about 10 miles from the cabin, according to court documents. Deli allegedly got out of the car and aimed a handgun at authorities and was then fired at by a Kamas police officer. The daughters were found inside the car unharmed. Before the proceeding, the men asked reporters if the story of the killings had been broadcast nationwide. When told it had, witnesses said they smiled. A preliminary hearing was scheduled for Jan. 8. The two men were ordered held without bail. In addition to the more serious charges, Deli was charged with assault and Taylor was charged with failure to respond to an officer's order to stop. The Summit County sheriff's office said the victims were part of a Humble, Texas family spending the holidays at the cabin about 45 miles east of Salt Lake City. Taylor and Deli were parolees from Utah State Prison who had been staying at the Orange Street Community Center in Salt Lake City, corrections department spokesman Dave Franchina said. They were declared walkaways from the halfway house when they failed to return from job hunting on Dec. 14. Taylor, who was serving a 1- to 15-year term for aggravated burglary, was paroled Oct. 23 and transferred to the halfway house on Nov. 23. Deli, imprisoned in 1989 on 5-year maximum term for arson, was paroled Nov. 27.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Officials Updating Pipeline Security In Face of Possible War
DOC.TEXT: The prospect of war in the Middle East has military and civilian security forces making extra sure they're ready to protect the 800-mile-long trans-Alaska oil pipeline from terrorists. America's most important oil lifeline also may be its most vulnerable, far removed from the continental United States and surrounded by wilderness. Its safety rests largely on a private firm under contract to Alyeska Pipeline Service Co., the consortium of oil companies running the pipeline, with plans for support from Alaska State Troopers, the Alaska National Guard and the Air Force, officials said. Security along the pipeline, at pump stations and the 1,000-acre tanker loading terminal in Valdez was tightened after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait in August, Alyeska officials said. Beyond that, security plans to combat terrorist threats are being upgraded at the request of Sen. Ted Stevens, R-Alaska. ``In August, I raised the question several times about the status of the contingency plans for the protection of the pipeline,'' Stevens said. Lt. Gen. Thomas McInerney, commander of the 11th Air Force in Alaska, was involved in the talks, he said. ``I'm assured there have been some meetings that have explored the degree of cooperation and coordination necessary'' to defend the pipeline, he said. ``They have (a) good (plan). I asked them to dust it off and make sure everybody understood it.'' The trans-Alaska oil pipeline, completed in 1977, is the jugular of domestic oil production. About 2 million barrels a day of North Slope crude - one quarter of all U.S. output - is pumped from Prudhoe Bay fields to the ice-free port of Valdez. Alyeska, National Guard and other federal officials would not discuss specific aspects of pipeline security, saying it reveal too much to terrorists. ``We are working on a draft plan,'' National Guard spokeswoman Kristine Schuster said. ``Alyeska is the lead agency here. ... The National Guard has been asked to give their input.'' ``I don't talk about it,'' said J.P. ``Pat'' Wellington, manager of corporate security for Alyeska. He oversees Alyeska's contract with American Guard Alert, Inc., which is in charge of physical security on the $9 billion pipeline. ``We are aware of what the security plans are, and we are happy with them,'' said Dave Vickery, spokesman for the U.S. Bureau of Land Management, which with the federal Department of Transportation and the state Division of Natural Resources monitors the pipeline. The 48-inch pipe, half of it buried and half of it elevated, was laid across 575 miles of BLM-managed land. It crosses 34 major rivers and 800 smaller streams. Seventy-thousand people helped build it. At least two telephone threats warning of possible attacks on the pipeline were reported in recent weeks, but neither claim could be substantiated and officials declined to discuss them. ``It's our policy not to confirm or deny the receipt of threats,'' said Tom Matthews, chief FBI agent in Alaska. Meanwhile, a source familiar with Alyeska security who asked not to be identified, said the pipeline company has been considering subscribing to a terrorism forecasting service. Despite the official worries, terrorism specialist Mike Ackerman of Ackerman Associates in Miami said the pipeline is an unlikely target of Arab extremists. Terrorists, if they strike inside the U.S., would probably hit public targets such as airports in Detroit or New York City, Ackerman said. And a possible attack on the pipeline would be unlikely to shut down oil flow for a significant period of time, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Precede LONDON
Hard-Line Iranian Newspaper Rejects Rushdie Concessions
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES thruout with hard-line Iranian newspaper rejecting Rushdie's concessions. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: A hard-line Tehran newspaper today rejected Salman Rushdie's efforts to end Moslem anger over his novel ``The Satanic Verses.'' It said the late Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini's death edict still stands. The British author announced Monday that he has embraced Islam and will not allow the book to be published in paperback. He also pledged that he would no longer seek to have the novel published in other languages. The novel has sold 1 million copies and already been translated into 15 languages. The book is banned by 20 countries. The Abrar daily said in an editorial that ``Khomeini's historic edict on Rushdie is irrevocable even if he (Rushdie) repents.'' In February 1989, the Iranian fundamentalist patriarch called on Moslems to seek out and kill Rushdie for allegedly blaspheming Islam in ``The Satanic Verses.'' Iran subsequently offered a $1 million bounty for Rushdie's death. Rushdie has been in hiding ever since. Rushdie announced his concessions to Moslems in a statement released in London by one of several Islamic leaders with whom he met in secret on Monday. Hesham el-Essawy, president of the Islamic Society for the Promotion of Religious Tolerance, said Rushdie had typed the statement himself. Essawy said Rushdie, who was born to a Moslem family in India and had previously said he did not consider himself a religious Moslem, now had ``a clean slate'' with the world's estimated 1 billion Moslems. But Abrar dismissed Rushdie's efforts as part of ``propaganda maneuvers by the British government aimed at bringing Rushdie out of isolation and making Moslems neglect'' Khomeini's edict. Although Essawy said that he and two other prominent Moslem scholars met with Rushdie, the newspaper claimed ``no British Moslem leader ... could confirm any such meeting.'' Iran severed relations with Britain over the Rushdie affair, accusing the London government of defaming Islam by allowing ``The Satanic Verses'' to be published. Relations were resumed Sept. 27 after British officials conceded that Rushdie's book offended Moslems and that London had no wish to offend Islam. The resumption of relations came amid efforts by Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani, leader of his country's so-called pragmatists, to build bridges with the West following the June 1989 death of Khomeini. The Iranians have not rescinded Khomeini's death sentence on Rushdie, claiming it is a religious edict that cannot be revoked. But Rafsanjani and his supporters have indicated they are prepared to allow the decree to lapse. Abrar's editorial reflected the thinking of hard-line radicals opposed to Rafsanjani's drive to boost relations with the West and Iran's Arab neighbors, as well as liberalize Iranian society. Rafsanjani has largely marginalized the radicals in a power struggle, but they continue to snipe at him. Rushdie said in a telephone hookup with a news conference Monday that it is up to Iranian leaders whether to withdraw the death sentence. But he added, ``I feel a lot safer tonight than I felt yesterday.'' Many Moslems worldwide object to Rushdie's use of the names of the Prophet Mohammed's wives for the prostitutes in his novel and the implication that Mohammed wrote the Koran, Islam's holy book, instead of receiving it from God. Some Moslem leaders in Britain were not satisfied with Rushdie's concessions, demanding that hardcover editions of ``The Satanic Verses'' be removed from bookstore shelves. Sher Azam of the Council for Mosques in Bradford in northern England, where the book had been publicly burned, sad: ``Until the book is completely removed our campaign goes on.''

DOC.HEAD: Soldiers Hit the Decks for Some Fun
With PM-World Xmas Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: A woman in a Santa Claus outfit greeted the first group of soldiers to unwind aboard a cruise liner offering Western-style diversions for Persian Gulf troops. The Pentagon paid $31 million for a six-month lease for the Cunard Princess, which features a swimming pool, two Jacuzzis, tennis courts, a nightclub, bars and a 40-foot black marble dance floor. Military officials in Saudi Arabia note there have been special problems in finding ways for U.S. soldiers to relax in a country where alcohol and mixing with the opposite sex are forbidden. The first group of desert-weary soldiers boarded Christmas Eve in Bahrain, a small island nation in the Persian Gulf. ``The cruise ship represents a vital part of our R&R program, and will provide a much needed respite for the personnel who have been in the desert since the beginning of the operation,'' said a U.S. Navy spokesman Cmdr. Mark Neuhart. Men and women from all branches of the military will be rotated every three days aboard the ship, which can accommodate 800 guests. Neuhart said ``there will be two to a cabin, but males and females will not be able to share rooms.'' ``Both officers and enlisted personnel will be on the ship together, however, most likely separated,'' he added. Entertainers other than the visiting USO shows are featured on the ship. Alcohol can be purchased on the ship at duty-free costs. Physicians and clergy will also be assigned to the liner. Cunard employees are staffing the ship, which will remain berthed while soldiers are on board. A second Cunard ship should be leased soon by the military, officials said. American and British families in Bahrain invited hundreds of military personnel to share a Christmas meal and other holiday festivities with them.

DOC.HEAD: Pope Prays Leaders Will Choose Dialogue Over Gulf War
DOC.BYLINE: With PM-World Xmas Rdp, Bjt ^By FRANCES D'EMILIO
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II prayed in his Christmas message today that political leaders will choose patience and dialogue over a war in the Persian Gulf, and noted that the Holy Land is also without peace. ``The light of Christ is with the tormented nations of the Middle East. For the area of the gulf we await with trepidation for the threat of conflict to disappear. May leaders be convinced that war is an adventure with no return.'' ``By reasoning, patience and dialogue with respect for the inalienable rights of peoples and nations, it is possible to identify and travel the paths of understanding and peace. ``The Holy Land, too, has been awaiting this peace for years: a peaceful solution to the whole question which concerns it, a solution which takes into account the legitimate expectations of the Palestinian people and of the people which lives in the state of Israel,'' the pope said. The pope, speaking from the central balcony of St. Peter's Basilica above a rain-drenched St. Peter's Square, also warned Europeans to resist materialism in wake of the ``tumbled walls of ideological and political opposition.'' In his traditional Christmas Day noon message ``urbi et orbi'' - Latin for ``to the city (of Rome) and the world'' - John Paul prayed that the light of Christmas also shine in Africa, ``where peace and harmony between different peoples and traditions is disrupted by fratricidal struggles, where hope for peace is still fragile and must be strengthened.'' After delivering the message, the pope wished the world Christmas joy in 53 languages, beginning in Italian and ended in Latin, the official language of the Roman Catholic church. The downpours which soaked Rome on Christmas Eve day and early today stopped shortly before the pope's main late-morning Christmas Mass in the basilica. The bad weather apparently kept the turnout down in the square, with only about 10,000 Romans, tourists and pilgrims gathered to hear the pope's message. Past years have seen crowds in the tens of thousands. The pope, wearing a white robe and a gold-banded, double-peaked hat, came out onto the balcony after saying Mass on the high altar of the basilica. Potted poinsettias sat snug around the bases of the twisted bronze columns supporting Bernini's canopy above the altar, which was ringed with bunches of yellow daisies and sprays of forsythia.

DOC.HEAD: Precede BETHLEHEM
Tension Overshadows Christmas Celebrations in Middle East
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 22 grafs to UPDATE with messages from pope, Archbishop of Canterbury, Queen Elizabeth. Picks up 20th graf pvs, `Germans marked ...' CHANGES byline
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II today prayed for world leaders to avoid war in the Persian Gulf and said the Palestinians must be considered in efforts for peace in the ``tormented nations of the Middle East.'' ``For the area of the gulf we await with trepidation for the threat of conflict to disappear,'' the pope said in a Christmas message delivered from the central balcony of St. Peter's Basilica in Vatican City. He also said a peaceful solution in Israeli-occupied lands must take ``into account the legitimate expectations of the Palestinian people.'' ``The light of Christ is with the tormented nations of the Middle East,'' the pontiff said. The fear of Palestinian unrest and the gulf crisis left the West Bank town of Bethlehem with one of its smallest Christmas crowds in recent memory. ``For us, Christmas is an event of peace, and here you cannot feel peace,''said German tourist Gabriele Beitz in Manger Square, near the grotto where tradition holds that Christ was born. The Christmas mood elsewhere in the Middle East was also anxious as U.S. troops in the gulf were placed on a heightened state of alert to guard against terrorist attacks. But soldiers still managed to mark the holiday with carols, decorations and desert religious services. Bethlehem's Christmas celebrations were canceled by the town's Palestinian officials in solidarity with the three-year uprising against Israeli occupation. Most shops and restaurants were closed. In past years, the town was crowded with pilgrims during Christmas and the streets were awash in colorful lights. But only several hundred people were in Manger Square as midnight Mass began at nearby St. Catherine's Church. The Roman Catholic patriarch of Jerusalem, Michel Sabah, prayed for a peaceful resolution of the gulf conflict. Jesus ``shows us the way of love we need today on the eve of a world war, especially under these circumstances, we need peace,'' he said in Arabic and French. Security was especially heavy in Bethlehem because of a wave of Arab attacks on Israelis after the Oct. 8 riot on Jerusalem's Temple Mount in which Israeli police killed 17 Palestinians. As a Christmas gesture, the military announced it was releasing 217 Palestinian prisoners. Most had less than a month to go in their sentences. For the estimated 300,000 U.S. troops in the gulf, Christmas festivities were muted by Saudi law that forbids practice of all religions except Islam. Carols such as ``Silent Night'' were sung behind closed tent flaps, and military chaplains were renamed morale officers before holding low-key services. Some soldiers, however, had some lively holiday diversions. The cruise liner Cunard Princess was turned into a Christmas Eve party spot off Bahrain, where a woman dressed as Santa Claus greeted troops on the gangplank. The Pentagon paid $31 million to lease the ship for six months for the troops. Comedian Bob Hope was also in the gulf, keeping to his longtime tradition of entertaining U.S. troops at Christmas. Britain's Archbishop of Canterbury Robert Runcie today said war in the gulf could only be justified ``if and when all other means of persuasion have failed.'' ``In such a combat thousands could suffer and die,'' said Runcie, who was a decorated tank officer in World War II. In London, Queen Elizabeth II thanked the multinational forces in the gulf for ``resisting the bully and the tyrant.'' She also condemned attacks by the Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland, where 75 people have died in violence so far this year. Germans marked their first Christmas since unification with a gesture of friendship to the Soviet Union. Money was collected to help ease the Soviet food shortage and some people in former East Germany invited Red Army soldiers over for the holiday. ``It's heart-to-heart contact, people to people,'' said Klaus Wuest of Berlin, whose family spend Christmas Eve with a 19-year-old Soviet soldier. ``The old regime was based on suspicion and hatred. Now we can be friendly.'' Dramatic changes were also celebrated in Albania, where a 23-year-old ban on religion was lifted in November. Roman Catholic priest Simon Jubani, who was jailed eight times by the former Stalinist regime, led Christmas Mass in a rundown chapel the northern city of Shkodra. ``For the first time in 23 years, there will be midnight Mass,'' Jubani said. ``Merry Christmas.'' In state-controlled churches in China, worshipers and the curious joined in prayer and song. For many in China, an officially atheist country, Christmas is viewed as an exotic foreign holiday. But department stores and hotels catering to foreigners often feature Christmas themes. ``I am not a believer,'' said one student who attended a service in Beijing, ``but I know this day is very important to some people here and people everywhere. I just want to learn a little about it.''

DOC.HEAD: Text of Pope's Christmas Message
DOC.TEXT: Here is the Vatican's official English translation of the annual Christmas ``Urbi et Orbi'' (to the city and to the world) message given by Pope John Paul II on Tuesday: --- At midnight the prophet Isaiah spoke to us. With inspired voice he proclaimed: ``The people who walked in darkness have seen a great light; those who dwelt in a land of deep darkness, on them has light shined.'' (Isaiah 9:2) A light has shined. Only the light seen by the shepherds at Bethlehem? Was it only that light which shone on the horizon? In truth, that light became a guiding sign, like the star which guided the Wise Men from the East. The light shone in a different way. It shone more clearly. To man's interior eyes God has revealed himself. In broad daylight the evangelist speaks to us, the apostle John: ``The true light that enlightens every man was coming into the world.'' (John 1:9). This light is born in God. It comes from God, It is God. It is the eternal word. The word is the Son, one of being with the Father, ``God from God, light from light.'' The word has come into the world. The word was made flesh. ``In him was life, and the life was the light of men. The light shines in the darkness, and the darkness has not overcome it.'' (John 1:4-5). The night persists. The night of advent. The peoples walk in darkness - yet the light is with them: the word who was made flesh in the midst of the nations. The word, in whom the unknowable God has made himself known to mankind, the word who is the Son. In him the word is eternally known and eternally loved. And he is the measure of this love, the divine measure: ``For God so loved the world that he gave his only Son.'' (John 3:16). The divine measure of love is the Gift: it is the Son as a gift. As the absolute gift, not comparable with other gifts: God - man. In him is life. Above the heritage of death, present in the world, man inherits the life which is from God; he inherits it in the Son, who became man on Bethlehem night and was born of the Virgin Mary. He was born by the power of the Holy Spirit, through whom is realized the absolute gift. The night persists. The night of advent. The peoples walk in darkness - yet with them is this absolute gift. He is present: the spirit of truth, revealed in the Son and by the Son. The light of the Son ceases not to be with man through the power of the spirit, who bears witness to him. He bears witness to the word who was made flesh and, on Bethlehem night, has come to dwell among us. Our earthly eyes see the child placed in a manger (cf. Luke 2:7), while the eyes of faith see the glory ``glory as of the only Son from the Father full of grace and truth.'' (John 1:14). On this day we ask for light: we ask that the eyes of our hearts be enlightened (cf. Ephesians 1:18). We ask for harmony and unity for families wounded by misunderstanding and torn by division. The night persists, but the light of Christ is with mankind. It is with the people in Europe; above the tumbled walls of ideological and political opposition there appear for believers demanding challenges and prospects. Yes, Europe's future will be filled with wonderful spiritual vitality, if hedonism and practical materialism are overcome and also if the barriers which divide the followers of the redeemer are broken down. Unity in the Church, and among all believers in Christ: this is the commitment of Christians for building the new Europe in the third millennium. The light of Christ is with the tormented nations of the Middle East. For the area of the (Persian) Gulf, we await with trepidation for the threat of conflict to disappear. May leaders be convinced that war is an adventure with no return. By reasoning, patience and dialogue with respect for the inalienable rights of peoples and nations, it is possible to identify and travel the paths of understanding and peace. The Holy Land too has been awaiting this peace for years: a peaceful solution to the whole question which concerns it, a solution which takes into account the legitimate expectations of the Palestinian people and of the people which lives in the state of Israel. May the light of Christ shine upon the continent of Africa, especially where freedom is compromised because of under development, where peace and harmony between different peoples and traditions is disrupted by fratricidal struggles, where hope for peace is still fragile and must be strengthened. I call once again for a more just sharing of the earth's resources, a new and more just world ethical and economic order. Only effective and respectful cooperation between the rich countries and the emerging peoples can prevent the contrast between north and south from becoming a widening abyss which will increase the already vast and disturbing archipelago of poverty and death. But the shadows, through they seem to be growing deeper on the horizon, cannot dim the light of Christ. To humanity seeking joy he offers the treasure of his own life: he gives himself, lavishing the signs of his love upon our weary present. How, for example, could we fail to bless him for the religious awakening today influencing so many people, young and old? How could we fail to thank him for the new openness of peoples to his gospel, to which the recent ad limina visit of numerous bishops from Vietnam also bears promising witness? Christ travels and lives with us. He is among us! Living and glorious in his triumph of mercy. Let humanity go to meet his unapproachable light, which today reveals itself to us with power. With the tongues of the peoples and nations let us ask for light.
