DOC.HEAD: Saddam Recalls Diplomats; Bush Told Troop Readiness Questioned
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with media reports Israeli army on heightened state of alert, Christians praying for peace in Baghdad, background. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto JV1
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi ambassadors headed home today for urgent consultations, and U.S. troops in the Saudi desert experienced a Christmas of contrast - peace and goodwill mixed with loneliness and a heightened state of alert. At Camp David, President Bush was reportedly told that some military leaders believe U.S. combat units in the Persian Gulf will not be ready for all-out war with Iraq by the Jan. 15 deadline imposed by the U.N. Security Council. Lt. Gen. Calvin Waller, deputy U.S. commander in Saudi Arabia, made a similar assessment last week during Defense Secretary Dick Cheney's visit. Saddam Hussein recalled his ambassadors from the United States, the United Nations and several Western European countries. Iraqi officials were not saying what would be discussed, but the call indicated Saddam could be planning a major diplomatic offensive. The Council has said Iraq must withdraw from Kuwait by Jan. 15 or face possible attack by the almost 400,000-strong U.S.-led multinational forces stationed in the gulf. Fear of terrorist attacks during the holiday season led U.S. military commanders in the gulf to order extra security precautions. Nevertheless, troops tried their best to bring a yuletide mood to the Saudi sands. A special Christmas feast was prepared using tons of supplies shipped in last month and Christmas carols were sung inside tents. Santa even made several appearances - one courtesy of Coast Guard Petty Officer 2nd Class Ron Sauers, 44, of Rochester, N.Y., who used toilet paper for a beard and wore a red stocking cap. Services were held by Protestant and Roman Catholic chaplains, renamed morale officers because of a Saudi law fobidding practice of all religions expect Islam in the kingdom. Thousands of Christians celebrated Christmas in Baghdad today and prayed for peace. Leaders of Iraq's 1.5 million Christians officiated at midnight masses and morning services across the Iraqi capital. Bush was reportedly told by Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, Monday that military commanders believe U.S. forces will not be ready for a full-scale attack on Iraq by the Jan. 15 deadline. Cheney and Powell returned Monday from a five-day trip to the gulf. The comments to Bush were reported by ABC-TV and The New York Times. Both cited unnamed sources. The Times said Bush was told many military officials recommend delaying any attack until February. Neither the White House nor the Defense Department provided details of the meeting. Waller's remarks appeared to have upset some officials in the Bush administration, which has sought to show itself unwavering in its determination to use force if Saddam refuses to quit Kuwait, which he seized on Aug. 2. Cheney said on Sunday that U.S. troops would be ``prepared today ... to take military action,'' adding that U.S. troop strength in the gulf is nearly 300,000. The Israeli media said today the Jewish state's military is on higher alert than ever and has moved extra forces to its eastern front, although army sources played down the reports. Banner headlines in most Israeli newspapers, and a report by Israel radio's military correspondent, spoke of a heightened military alert and reinforcements along the border with Jordan, which lies between Israel and Iraq. The reports came the day after Israeli Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir said the danger of a gulf war was ``very close,'' and Foreign Minister David Levy warned Jordan to ``not allow any adventurer to use its land or air space for the purpose of attacking Israel.'' Saddam said over the weekend he would attack Tel Aviv first if war broke out over Kuwait. But military sources said on condition of anoymity that a military alert had been in force since the start of the gulf crisis. They said they were not aware of any buildup on the Jordan border. In other developments: -Comedian Bob Hope was in the gulf today entertaining troops. Hope first visited U.S. troops for Christmas shows in 1941. -On Monday, about 500 mourners gathered at Mayport Naval Station near Jacksonville, Fla., for ceremonies to honor the 21 sailors from the USS Saratoga killed in a ferry boat accident off Israel.

DOC.HEAD: Five Dead in Christmas Fire
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with search for possible sixth victim ended; DELETES report of resident attempting rescue, which hasn't been confirmed. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: A Christmas morning fire raced through a house, killing five people, authorities said. Fire Division Battalion Chief James Siemer said the victims included two children. They were not identified immediately. A visitor to the home, Todd Allen, 29, said he awakened to the smell of smoke and escaped through a window, cutting his bare feet on glass. He said he climbed down a ladder put up by firefighters. The cause of the fire has not been determined. Firefighters searched the rubble for a possible sixth victim and concluded no one else was inside, said Fire Capt. Bruce Sutton. The fire started on the first floor of the 2{-story house and caused $30,000 damage, he said. One firefighter was slightly injured in a fall.

DOC.HEAD: Military Seizes Control In Former Dutch Colony
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to UPDATE with Dutch condemning takeover. Pickup 4th pvs, `In 1980...'
DOC.TEXT: The armed forces appeared in control of this former Dutch colony today after toppling the nearly 3-year-old elected government in what two former Surinamese officials called a bloodless coup. The Dutch government today condemned the military takeover Monday night, and Dutch TV said no one was arrested in the coup. The takeover followed a dispute between President Ramsewak Shankar and long-time military chief Lt. Col. Desi Bouterse, who had resigned earlier in the day. There were no reports of shooting and Shankar's whereabouts were not known. Dutch Foreign Ministry spokesman Dig Istha said that practically all communication lines out of Suriname were still cut this afternoon. Dutch television quoted an Surinamese Embassy spokesman as saying that no one has been put under arrest in the coup, reportedly led by the acting commander of the Dutch forces, Ivan Graanoogst. Observers in the Netherlands believed the coup was masterminded by Bouterse. In 1980, Bouterse led a military coup that toppled a legitimately elected government in the small mineral-rich country on South America's northeastern tip. He ruled until elections in November 1987, which Shankar's Front for Democracy and Development party won by a landslide. Relations between the government and Bouterse have been strained ever since Shankar began serving a five-year term on Jan. 25, 1988, with Bouterse wielding considerable power by virtue of his control of the military. In Amsterdam, Netherlands, a former high-ranking Surinamese official who spoke with Bouterse after Monday's coup said the military had acted after the government reneged on a pledge to step down. Graanoogst announced the takeover on Surinamese television late Monday, according to Dutch TV and former Surinamese diplomat living in a nearby country. The former diplomat said the coup appeared to have been bloodless and quoted Graanoogst as saying a curfew was in effect. Graanoogst urged his countrymen to remain calm and said the military had everything under control. The former Surinamese official in Amsterdam said the army had promised to form an interim government that would organize free elections within 100 days and that Bouterse had assured him that no shots were fired during the coup. The official, Andre J. Haakmat, was minister of justice and minister of the army from 1980-82 by went into exile after a dispute with Bouterse. Earlier Monday night, a Surinamese newspaper reporter told The Associated Press bureau in San Juan, Puerto Rico that the military had overthrown the government. The telephone line went dead after a few minutes and the reporter, who did not want to be identified by name, was unable to give further details. Later, all telephone and telex lines to Suriname went out of service. In Washington, the State Department had no immediate comment. In a dispute with Shankar, Bouterse announced Saturday that he intended to resign as head of the military in this nation of 380,000 people. He was angered by treatment he had received at Amsterdam's Schiphol Airport and accused Shankar of collaborating with Dutch officials who refused to grant him a visa or allow him access to journalists. ``If I had been in Shankar's place I would have turned Schiphol upside down to protect the dignity of the commander of my country's national army,'' Bouterse said Saturday, returning from a trip via Amsterdam to Ghana and Switzerland. Haakmat said the government had promised to step down in a meeting Monday with Bouterse and other military leaders but reneged immediately afterward. ``The government is being accused of failing to uphold Surinamese national dignity,'' said Haakmat. ``In the two years they were in power, they could not solve any of the problems in the country.'' The Dutch government said Bouterse was kept from the public at the Amsterdam airport for security reasons, because Bouterse might be at risk from the thousands of his political opponents who are living in The Netherlands. The Dutch foreign ministry warned over the weekend that a ``coup ... will have a detrimental effect on development aid.'' A $1.5-billion annual Dutch aid package to Suriname, which gained independence in 1975, was suspended after 15 prominent opposition leaders were killed on Dec. 8, 1982 by Bouterse's military government. Bouterse had accused the leaders at the time of plotting to overthrow him. But the suspension of the aid package only deepened the economic crisis that beset the country after Bouterse took power, and the weak economy has contributed to the political instability. Suriname has suffered from a drop in the price of bauxite, its primary foreign exchange earner. Suriname is a multiracial nation whose population consists of Indians, Javanese, Bush Negroes and indigenous tribes. Much of the country is covered by heavy jungle, making both communications and internal security difficult.

DOC.HEAD: Bitter Cold Keeps Hold on West
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 6th graf, `In Alaska...', to CORRECT spelling of Albuquerque. Inserts 2 grafs after the 11th graf, `It will...', to UPDATE with temps today in Calif and East, picking up 12th graf, `Frozen water...'; SUBS penultimate grf to add that Calder is in Idaho. Other minor editing.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Cold-Crops, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Stubborn cold in the West that dropped temperatures below those in Alaska left songbirds lying frozen dead on the ground in California, froze a cash register shut in New Mexico and threatened flooding along ice-clogged rivers. It was one of the coldest Christmas Eves ever in Utah, where records were knocked off the books by 15-degree margins. Record subzero lows were recorded at 20 Utah sites and the mercury dropped to 44 below in the Cache Valley. It was 32 below in Gallup, N.M. - so cold that the cash register wouldn't open at Kristy's Coffee Shop unless cashiers thawed it with a portable heater. ``It's colder here than it is where my parents are in Alaska. And the last time I talked to my parents it was only 20 below,'' said Tracey Francis of the Sunwest Bank in Gallup. Meteorologist Allan Rowell in Albuquerque, N.M., said the reading of 38 below zero at Dulce made the city the coldest in the nation on Monday. In Alaska early today, it was 34 degrees in Anchorage and 8 degrees in Fairbanks. Boise, Idaho, was 16 below, and Albuquerque was 5. Readings of 20 below zero or colder were reported Monday in Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, Colorado, New Mexico, Utah and Nevada. The number of deaths blamed on the weather since the record cold snap began rose to at least 79 by Monday. Most were traffic deaths blamed on slippery roads. Other people were killed by hypothermia, tornadoes and house fires. In Santa Cruz, Calif., people reported songbirds lying frozen dead on the ground after a record low of 19 - the coldest temperature ever recorded in the seaside city about 80 miles south of San Francisco. Temperatures were expected to rise slightly today through Friday before another cold wave from the north prepared to sock the West. ``It will be a little bit warmer than the last blast, but it's all relative,'' said meteorologist Jim Shadwick in Boise, Idaho. His counterpart in Salt Lake City, William Alder, said it ``could be a repeat performance.'' Temperatures were expected to reach as high as the mid-60s today in parts of California, but it was still cold this morning. San Bernardino registered 32 degrees at 2 a.m., as did Oceanside. And in the San Joaquin Valley, farmers who already have declared their navel orange crop lost got a fourth straight freezing night, with Fresno reporting 25 degrees at 2 a.m. No warming trend was in sight in the East, where a run of record high temperatures ended abruptly Monday when the cold air arrived. New York was at 24 early today, and Philadelphia was at 21, readings some 40 degrees lower than the Monday's early morning readings. Frozen water pipes continued to burst throughout the region, and the cold weather caused a jump in house fires and made firefighting more difficult. ``In the last seven days, there's been an inordinately large number of fires,'' said Lt. Greg Keller, an investigator with the fire department in Portland, Ore. The cold snap affected Christmas sales as temperatures in the teens in Oregon burst more water pipes and created havoc. ``I look for the Saturday before Christmas to be my biggest day of the year,'' said owner Rich Hansen of Gold & Gems in Ashland, Ore. A power outage cost him up to $10,000 in sales, he said. ``We were absolutely devastated.'' Only eight of the 79 rooms at the Bard's Inn Motel in Ashland could be rented because broken pipes had caused major water damage, said Teresa Loe, assistant manager. In Idaho and Washington state, huge ice floes clogged several rivers and threatened to overflow their banks. Along the St. Joe River, crews on Sunday failed to blast a channel through a 2-mile ice jam near Calder, Idaho. ``We have a serious situation developing. We've got miles of frozen river,'' said Harold Van Asche, disaster services coordinator for Shoshone County. ``It's so massive there's not much we can do.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf of GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK, Wyo.-dated first item to CORRECT spelling of tepees.
DOC.TEXT: Kevin Costner considered filming ``Dances With Wolves'' in Grand Teton National Park but switched to a South Dakota location when park officials wouldn't let them use a choice site. ``The request was to provide a campsite of 40 tepees on a river with the Tetons in the background,'' said Marshall Gingery, the park's assistant superintendent. Park officials recommended a site along the Snake River north of Moose, which was turned down by the filmmakers. They wanted to make Deadman's Bar, which sits along the Snake River with the Tetons in the background, into a campsite. But park officials didn't think it could withstand the heavy use it would have received during the filmmaking. ``We felt the resource was not able to tolerate that disturbance,'' Gingery said. Gingery also said officials were concerned about what off-road traffic might do to the area. ``They were talking about boom trucks. We didn't want any vehicles off the road - in the cottonwoods, especially,'' he said. Gingery said the decision to move the film to South Dakota probably was for the best because the terrain there is ``probably more typical for the Sioux.''

DOC.HEAD: Parliament Approves Gorbachev Plan for More Presidential Powers
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 15 grafs to UPDATE with parliament approving Gorbachev plan for expanded presidential powers. Pickup 16th pvs, `The amendments...'
DOC.TEXT: Parliament today voted to give sweeping new powers to President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, approving his ideas for a new vice presidency and Cabinet under his direct control. The approval of new powers by the 2,250-member Congress of People's Deputies was a clear victory for Gorbachev, and a triumph for the hard-line lawmakers whom Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze cited last week in his stunning resignation. He said hard-liners were pushing the country to ``dictatorship.'' The parliament voted today to eliminate Gorbachev's moribund Presidential Council, form a new Federation Council with Gorbachev as its chief, and create a powerful new vice presidency subordinate to Gorbachev. They approved a bill placing the proposed new Cabinet of Ministers under Gorbachev's direct control, as opposed to the current Council of Ministers's subordination to the national Supreme Soviet legislature. The parliament also fell short of the two-thirds majority needed to approve a bill that would require legislative approval for Gorbachev's presidential decrees. The president currently can issue his sweeping orders without any oversight, although many republics have been ignoring the decrees and adding to the breakdown of order. The votes came after Boris N. Yeltsin, leader of the Soviet Union's most populous republic, condemned the plans to broaden Gorbachev's power and said he would vote against them. The Soviet president claims the reforms are needed to hold together a country being threatened with collapse by separatists movements and economic chaos. Each of the republics have declared some form of political independence or economic autonomy, seeking to supercede national laws with their own. The Gorbachev-proposed amendments would replace the Council of Ministers and its prime minister, Nikolai Ryzhkov, with a smaller 15-member Cabinet and a more powerful vice president, all under direct presidential control. They also would give more power to Gorbachev's Federation Council of representatives from the 15 republics. Debate began today with one deputy suggesting Gorbachev should give up some of his posts in the reorganization. ``Don't you feel sorry for Mikhail Sergeyevich Gorbachev? He has only one life to live,'' Erkin Yusupov, a deputy from Uzbekistan, told the Congress. ``He has a family, children, grandchildren. He is (Communist Party) general secretary. He is president. He is responsible for the Council of Ministers. In the end, we have to consider ... how much is one person capable of doing.'' Gorbachev, who has attended every session since the Congress opened Dec. 17, said he would keep the jobs in the government and party. The president also indicated Shevardnadze had agreed to remain foreign minister during the congress, scheduled to end Thursday. ``Shevardnadze, I believe, is a man who has done a lot and will still do a lot,'' Gorbachev told reporters today. ``The question of where and how will continue'' to be discussed. The amendments on presidential power include provisions that would prohibit the vice president from being a member of Congress, said Alexander Kudryavtsev, chairman of the amendment drafting commission. Nearly every senior leader, including the few people thought to be candidates for the vice presidency, is a deputy in the Congress. Kudryavtsev also said the draft calls for the Federation Council to include representatives of the 15 republics and the 20 smaller ``autonomous republics,'' which are under republic jurisdiction. That would give the Council about 150 members, which Kudryavtsev likened to a small ``general assembly.'' On Monday, Congress ordered each republic to hold a referendum asking residents whether they want to remain in a restructured Soviet Union, and another on whether people should be allowed to own land privately. Private property ownership already has been approved by the Russian legislature, which has authority over three-quarters of the country's land and control of 90 percent of its energy supplies. Yeltsin has said there is no need for a referendum. Congress also endorsed the concept of a new Union Treaty to keep the union together and voted to keep ``socialist'' as part of the country's name.

DOC.HEAD: Strong Quake Shakes Northeastern Taiwan
DOC.TEXT: A strong earthquake shook northeastern Taiwan on Tuesday night but there were no immediate reports of casualties or damage, authorities said. The Central Weather Bureau said the quake registered 6.2 on the Richter scale. The epicenter was 7{ miles south of the eastern city of Hualien, 108 miles southeast of Taipei. Weather forecasters said seven minor temblors shook the Hualien area on Tuesday, and they also were felt in Taipei, the capital. Police said there were no immediate reports of injuries or damage. The Richter scale measures ground motion as recorded on seismographs. Every increase of one number means a 10-fold increase in intensity. An earthquake of magnitude 6 can cause severe damage in a populated area, while one measuring 7 is classified as a major earthquake, capable of causing widespread, heavy damage.

DOC.HEAD: Suriname at a Glance
With AM-Suriname
DOC.TEXT: Here are some facts and figures on Suriname: --- THE LAND - About the size of Georgia, the 63,037-square-mile tropical nation is on the northeastern slope of South America between Guyana on the west and French Guiana on the east. Its 100-mile southern border adjoins Brazil in the depths of the Amazon rain forest. Half the country's nearly 400,000 people live in the Atlantic coast capital of Paramaribo. --- THE PEOPLE - One of world's most ethnically diverse countries, the former Dutch colony's population is made up mainly of East Indians, Creoles - descendants of African slaves - and Indonesians. They live mostly along the Atlantic coast. The jungle interior is sparsely inhabited by Maroons, who make up 10 percent of the population. They are descendants of runaway African slaves and indigenous Indians. The races are often divided along political lines. Religions include Hindu, Moslem, Roman Catholic, Moravian, Jewish and several Protestant denominations. The official language is Dutch, but the most commonly spoken language is lingua franca Sranang Tongo, or Taki-Taki. Many also speak English. --- HISTORY - First sighted by Columbus in 1498. English begin settling in 1651, starting cocoa, coffee, sugar and cotton plantations. The Netherlands acquires territory from Britain through Treaty of Breda in 1667, which cedes New Amsterdam, now New York, to England. In the 18th and 19th centuries, Suriname passes hands to England, France and back to the Netherlands in 1815. Becomes independent on Nov. 25, 1975, as a parliamentary democracy. Coup of Feb. 25, 1980, results from labor dispute between the army and government. Sgt. Maj. Desi Bouterse emerges as the leader, dissolves parliament and rules by decree. On Dec. 8, 1982, army arrests 15 opposition leaders, executes them while in detention. The Netherlands and United States cut economic aid. In October 1987, Bouterse allows elections, opposition parties win by landslide, form three-party coalition and appoint Ramsewak Shankar as president. Bouterse returns Saturday from the Netherlands, calls Shankar a ``joker'' he can no longer serve, announces resignation. Civilian government overthrown Monday. --- ECONOMY - Before 1980 coup, Suriname was one of most prosperous countries in South America, with per capita gross national product of $3,500. By 1985 per capita GNP drops to $2,500. Up to 10 percent of the populace emigrates to the Netherlands, French Guiana and other countries. Four factors contribute to economic decline after 1980 coup: Army sergeants unprepared for leadership, drop in world bauxite prices, the Netherlands cuts $1.5 billion aid package after December 1982 massacre of civic leaders, Jungle Command guerrilla warfare curtails activity in bauxite-producing eastern part of country. Suriname has some of world's richest deposits of bauxite, raw material of aluminum. Bauxite is the major foreign exchange earner. Other exports are shrimp, timber, bananas, palm oil and vegetables. Foreign reserves depleted by 1984. Jungle Command, led by former soldier Ronny Brunswijk, a Maroon, closes bauxite mines and aluminum shelters in 1986. After elections, Brunswijk reaches peace accord with new government. Army opposes terms of agreement and fighting resumes. The Netherlands agrees to resume aid after election, but scraps the plan after Surinamese coup.

DOC.HEAD: Police Officer Kills Two at His Home
DOC.TEXT: A police officer shot to death two people when a gang of armed men entered his home and threatened his family early on Christmas Day, police said. Police Capt. Eugene Opperman said the incident in the black township of Kagiso occurred after midnight when the officer heard a commotion and confronted four men in his home. The men threatened to kill the officer and his family and destroy the house, Opperman said. When one pointed a pistol at the officer, he drew his service revolver and fired five shots, the police captain said. The bodies of two people, including one holding a pistol, were found outside the house, Opperman said. Black policemen in townships have come under attack from residents who accuse them of collaborating with white authorities and perpetuating the apartheid system of racial segregagtion.

DOC.HEAD: Inquiry Begins Into Allegations Against Deposed President
DOC.TEXT: A government commission on Tuesday asked citizens to volunteer information on alleged corruption by deposed President Hussain Muhammad Ershad and his senior officials. The three-member investigative commission began work Monday to gather evidence and recommend legal action, said a statement published in Tuesday's newspapers. The statement asked people to submit any information on misdeeds by the former government through the mail or in person. The commission is headed by Supreme Court Justice Delwar Muhammad Ansaruddin Ahmed. Ershad, a former army general who seized power in a bloodless coup in 1982, was placed under house arrest on Dec. 12, six days after he relinquished power. Ershad's ouster and replacement by a caretaker government followed nearly two months of anti-government protests. His administration was widely suspected of corruption and abusing power. Police so far have arrested Ershad, his wife, Raushan, and three former Cabinet ministers. They also detained Zeenat Musharaf, who has been linked romantically with Ershad and who allegedly benefited from business favors, and her husband, Musharaf Hussain, a leading businessman. Arrest warrants have been issued for another 11 top officials of Ershad's ousted government. The student protesters have demanded an immediate trial. They have criticized the caretaker administration for failing to arrest Ershad's close advisers, who are accused of making millions of dollars through corrupt practices.

DOC.HEAD: Mazda To Recall 3,498 Passenger Cars For Defective Switches
DOC.TEXT: Madza Motor Corp. of Japan will recall 3,498 Luce model passenger cars because of switch defects in their stop lights and cruise control mechanisms, the automaker said Tuesday. A Transport Ministry official, meanwhile, said the government told Mazda to pay more attention to the safety of its cars. Of the cars to be recalled, 134 were exported to Middle Eastern countries, said Mazda spokesman Kingo Okitsu. The others were sold in Japan. Okitsu said Mazda had notified the Transport Ministry of the recall. Because of the defective switches, stop lights may not work even if the driver hits the brakes, and the cruise control may not turn off, Okitsu said. The government's warning came after the Transport Ministry investigated allegations that Mazda had been replacing defective parts during routine maintenance without recalling the cars or notifying the government, said the ministry official, who spoke on condition of annymity. Okitsu said the recalled cars were produced between Aug. 8, 1986, and Jan. 31, 1987. The mass-circulation newspaper Asahi Shimbun reported on Dec. 16 that Mazda was quietly fixing defects that should have led to a recall.

DOC.HEAD: Three Killed In Gas Cylinder Explosion
DOC.TEXT: A gas cylinder slipped off a pushcart and exploded on a road in Dhaka's crowded old city, killing three people and injuring 20 others, police and doctors said Tuesday. A police official said two people died immediately and a third died on the way to hospital. Two of the victims were women, he said. Doctors at the Dhaka Medical College Hospital said of two of the injured were in serious condition, including a rickshaw puller who lost both legs and an eye.

DOC.HEAD: Poll: Europeans Believe Japan Shirking Global Responsibilities
DOC.TEXT: A majority of people surveyed in major European countries have a favorable view of Japan but believe it is not fulfilling its international responsibilities, the Foreign Ministry reported Tuesday. Among the chief criticisms was that Japan needs to correct its trade imbalance. However, many respondents said the creation of the European single market planned for 1992 will improve relations between Japan and the European Community, the ministry said in a news release. It was the sixth such poll conducted by Japan since 1977. It was carried out from September through October by private research organizations in each of the countries surveyed: Britain, France, Germany, Belgium, Italy, the Netherlands and Spain. In all seven countries, ``the degree of trust in Japan is rather high,'' ranging from 71 percent to 91 percent, the ministry said. In every country except Italy, however, a majority of respondents thought Japan was not fulfilling its international role. Japan, the world's No. 2 economic power, has come under criticism for not doing more to assist U.S.-led forces in the Persian Gulf and to ease its chronic trade surpluses. Many respondents called for a prompt correction of Japan's trade surplus with the EC, which totaled $1.49 billion in November. The most commonly cited recommendation was for Japan to open its markets more and expand domestic demand. Among other findings, according to a summary released by the ministry: -Expectations for direct investment from Japan were high in every country. -Business development by Japanese companies in Eastern Europe was ``generally desired.'' But most respondents said Japanese companies should invest only in cooperation with Western European countries. In Germany, however, 71 percent said the Japanese should get involved on their own. The survey, sponsored by the Foreign Ministry, was conducted by mail in Britain, western Germany and Belgium with responses from 1,543 out of 6,550 people to whom questionnaires were mailed. In the other countries, interviews were conducted with a total of 1,936 people. The poll did not give a margin of error. Japanese pollsters do not calculate such margins, claiming they might mislead readers into thinking a poll is more accurate than it really is.

DOC.HEAD: Central China Province Forms Special Teams to Fight Drug Problems
DOC.TEXT: Officials in the central province of Shaanxi have formed a special anti-drug force to combat narcotics trafficking and abuse, the Legal Daily newspaper reported Tuesday. The state newspaper said 184 people were convicted of drug-related crimes in Shaanxi in the first 10 months of this year. It gave no details. Shaanxi officials said the illegal trade and drug abuse have increased dramatically over the past three years. Authorities in other regions of China also have expressed alarm over the country's increasing drug problems. Chinese courts in Shaanxi and other provinces have begun to impose stiff sentences for drug crimes - in some cases even the death penalty. The Legal Daily said authorities broke up three smuggling networks bringing drugs into Shaanxi from other provinces such as Yunnan this year. Yunnan, in southwestern China, borders the ``Golden Triangle,'' an area including parts of Thailand, Laos and Burma that has been one of the largest sources of opium for the world's heroin supply. Yunnan also has been a gateway for smugglers carrying drugs through southwestern China to Hong Kong for shipment abroad. The Legal Daily said authorities from Shaanxi and the neighboring province of Henan worked together to crush two regional drug-trafficking networks involving more than 20 people. It said that in addition to the legal crackdown, the special team set up in Shaanxi will increase efforts to curb drug use. Addicts will receive treatment to help break their drug habits and education programs have been started to prevent others from using illegal narcotics, the newspaper said. China's drug problem was virtually eliminated after the Communists came to power in 1949, but it has re-emerged in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Kashmir Guerrillas Refuse to Negotiate, Punjab Leader Ready
DOC.TEXT: A leader of a militant Moslem group in Kashmir state rejected Prime Minister Chandra Shekhar's offer Tuesday to negotiate with the rebels, who want to secede from India. But in Punjab, where Sikh militants also are fighting for secession, a prominant political leader said he was prepared to talk to the government - if he received a formal invitation, including a written agenda. A day earlier, in the far eastern state of Assam, the army captured a top leader of the United Liberation Front of Assam and 25 other group members in a month-old offensive to crush the separatist movement, a newspaper reported. India has suspended local government in all three states and placed them under federal rule in an effort to control guerrilla operations and terrorism, which have left thousands of people dead this year. The violence and religious conflict helped topple the government of former Prime Minister V.P. Singh last month. Chandra Shekhar has repeatedly offered to negotiate with any rebel group on condition talks cover issues that fall within the constitution. The wording of the offer, however, rules out talks on breaking away from India. On Tuesday, authorities freed Abdul Ahad Gurd, a leading advocate of Kashmiri independence, on a monthlong parole. He was arrested in Septermber. United News of India described Gurd's release as a move toward opening a dialogue with Kashmiri militants. But Ghulam Qadir Wani, spokesman of the Jammu-Kashmir Liberation Front, dismissed Chandra Shekhar's offer to talk, in an interview published Tuesday in the Hindustan Times, an independent English-language daily. The Liberation Front is the largest of many separatist factions in the northern Jammu-Kashmir state. Wani was quoted as accusing Indian security forces of the ``massacre of Kashmiri youth and the rape of young women.'' ``Should we bind ourselves to the terms and conditions of such a constitution and sit across the negotiating table?'' the paper quoted him as asking. Most militants seek independence for Jammu-Kashmir, the only state with a Moslem majority in Hindu-dominated India. Some groups want to unite with Moslem Pakistan, but others have called for a plebiscite to choose their future. Wani, speaking from a hideout, was quoted as saying Kashmiris ``have become conscious of their rights ... and now they are ready to make any sacrifice for this cause.'' In Punjab, Simranjit Singh Mann said he was prepared to talk about self-determination for the wealthy farming state, where Sikhs have a bare majority. Overall, Sikhs are only 2 percent of India's 880 million people. Mann was elected to Parliament in 1989 at the head of the largest Sikh faction, but resigned his seat last year. He is known to be close to some guerrilla factions but is opposed by others as too moderate. Extremists have killed more than 3,200 people this year in Punjab, in the most violent12 months since Sikhs launched their independence campaign in 1983. Another 1,700 people have died in Kashmir since the government began a crackdown on the separatist movement a year ago. India has accused Pakistan of supporting the guerrillas in the two border states with training and weapons. Islamabad says it provides only moral and political support to the secessionists. Press Trust of India reported that army troops arrested a senior leader of the United Liberation Front of Assam, in what was called a major breakthrough in the government's search-and-destroy mission against the Front. So far, about 1,000 suspected Front guerrillas have been captured since the offensive was launched on Nov. 28, but most leaders have escaped, reportedly across the border to Burma. The Front has been fighting a separatist campaign since 1988, claiming the state was being stripped of its revenues from its rich tea plantations and oil fields. At least two tea companies had closed their operations because of kidnappings and extortion before the government imposed federal rule and sent in the army.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T: We Made A Mistake When `Free' Callers From Gulf Were Billed
DOC.TEXT: About 25,000 families and friends of people serving in the Persian Gulf were mistakenly billed for calls that were supposed to be free, and the charges will be canceled, AT&T officials said Tuesday. American Telephone & Telegraph Co. had offered to let servicemen and women in the Gulf to make the free calls during Thanksgiving week, of Nov. 20 to Nov. 27, and 140,000 calls were made. But some local phone companies did not follow through on instructions not to bill the troops' families for these calls, company spokesman Richard Wallersteinsaid. The calls were placed to families all over the United States. Wallerstein said no one will have to pay for the bills, no matter how high they were. He said he had heard some of the bills had reached $500, but had no definitive information. The Washington Post reported Tuesday that bills sent to some soldiers' families soared as high as $2,000. The offer was for one three-minute call per soldier, but Wallerstein said AT&T had no way to enforce the limit. AT&T first offered free calls home for a week in mid-October, then renewed the offer for Thanksgiving. A total of about 275,000 calls were made. Each offer cost the company more than $1 million, Wallerstein said. Meanwhile, AT&T announced Monday a free call-home campaign for U.S. Navy sailors and Marines stationed on ships in the Middle East. The offer is good through New Year's Eve, and Wallerstein said he didn't expect any problems. ``We'll just do the bills right this time,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Prayers for Peace And Preparations for War on Christmas Day
LaserPhoto ROM1
DOC.TEXT: Pope John Paul II prayed for peace on Christmas Day as world leaders spoke worriedly of the prospect of war in the Persian Gulf. U.S. soldiers' thoughts turned to loved ones as they spent a somber holiday far from home. Germans marked their first Christmas since their national unification, and Albanians were free to celebrate a religious holiday for the first time in more than two decades. In Bethlehem, the site of Jesus' birth, soldiers patrolled the city. Crowds were small and the atmosphere subdued because of the gulf crisis and the 3-year-old Palestinian uprising, which has sharply cut tourism to the Holy Land. ``The light of Christ is with the tormented nations of the Middle East,'' the pontiff said in a Christmas message delivered from the central balcony of St. Peter's Basilica in rain-soaked Vatican City. ``For the area of the gulf we await with trepidation for the threat of conflict to disappear,'' the pope said. ``May leaders be convinced that war is an adventure with no return.'' John Paul said a peaceful solution in Israeli-occupied lands must take ``into account the legitimate expectations of the Palestinian people.'' The fear of Palestinian unrest and the gulf crisis left Bethlehem with one of its smallest Christmas crowds in recent memory. ``For us, Christmas is an event of peace, and here you cannot feel peace,''said German tourist Gabriele Beitz in Manger Square, near the grotto where tradition holds that Christ was born. In Albania, where a 23-year-old ban on religion was lifted in November, Roman Catholic priest Simon Jubani led Christmas Mass in a rundown chapel in the northern city of Shkodra. The Croatian news agency HINA reported that more than 30,000 Catholics attended the Mass, which would make it the biggest such celebration in postwar Albania. Security forces were on hand, but no incidents were reported, the news agency said. It said another 500 worshipers attended a Mass in Tirana, Albania's capital. ``For the first time in 23 years, there will be midnight Mass,'' said Jubani, who was jailed eight times by the former Stalinist regime. ``Merry Christmas.'' In his message, John Paul said the fall of communist rule in Eastern Europe last year poses ``demanding challenges'' for Catholics in the region. ``Europe's future will be filled with wonderful spiritual vitality if hedonism and practical materialism are overcome,'' he said. In and around the Persian Gulf, tens of thousands of American troops were on a heightened state of alert to guard against any attacks. But soldiers still celebrated the holiday with carols, decorations and religious services. Christmas festivities in Saudi Arabia, where the bulk of the U.S. troops are deployed, were muted to avoid offending the Islamic Saudis. Carols such as ``Silent Night'' were sung behind closed tent flaps, and military chaplains held low-key services. Servicemen aboard the aircraft carrier USS Saratoga were still mourning the loss of 21 crewmen in the sinking of an Israeli ferry on Saturday. The ferry capsized as it was bringing the men back to the Saratoga after shore leave in Israel. Crewmen ferried to Haifa, Israel, to telephone home on Christmas, but said they had little inclination to celebrate. ``Any plans I had of having me a good time died with the guys on Saturday,'' said a sailor from Louisiana, who spoke on condition of anonymity. ``I'm going to go straight back to the ship and have a quiet Christmas after I phone home.'' In London, Queen Elizabeth II thanked the multinational forces in the gulf for ``resisting the bully and the tyrant.'' She also condemned attacks by the Irish Republican Army in Northern Ireland, where 75 people have died in violence so far this year. The archbishop of Canterbury, Robert Runcie, said war in the Persian Gulf could only be justified ``if and when all other means of persuasion have failed.'' ``In such a combat thousands could suffer and die,'' said Runcie, who was a decorated tank officer in World War II. Germans marked Christmas as one nation with a gesture of friendship to the Soviet Union. Money was collected to help ease Soviet food shortages and some people in former East Germany invited Red Army soldiers over for the holiday. In China, an officially atheist country, worshipers and the curious joined in prayer and song in state-controlled churches. ``I am not a believer,'' said one student who attended a service in Beijing, ``but I know this day is very important to some people here and people everywhere. I just want to learn a little about it.'' In his message, the pope also spoke of Africa, ``disrupted by fratricidal struggles, where hope for peace is still fragile and must be strengthened.'' However, the pontiff said the light of Christmas broke through the ``shadows'' of some world conflicts. He pointed to communist Vietnam's granting permission to bishops to travel to Rome to meet with him. The Vatican said the pope's message was broadcast in about 60 countries, including Poland, Bulagria, Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Romania and the Soviet Union, which have all established formal ties with the Vatican since 1989.

President Bush spent a secluded Christmas with his family Tuesday - a holiday overshadowed by the possibility that soon he may have to order American troops to war. Bush and his wife Barbara were at Camp David in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains, about 60 miles north of Washington, with their children and grandchildren, spokesman Steve Hart said. The holiday menu included turkey, cranberry sauce, green beans, sweet potatoes, and pie, Hart said. Bush was not expecting visitors and planned no special activities for the day, he said. But although his stay at Camp David through Jan. 2 is billed as a vacation, the president will work several hours every day and receive reports on developments around the world, Hart said. Bush decided to forgo his traditional Texas turkey hunt this year so he could stay close to Washington and monitor the Persian Gulf crisis, aides said. In his Christmas message to U.S. troops, Bush promised he would try to bring them home ``without a single shot fired.'' But if they must fight, he added, ``the sacrifices you make will never be forgotten.'' On Christmas Eve Bush conferred at Camp David with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Gen. Colin L. Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff. Both had just returned from five days in Saudi Arabia. The two reportedly told Bush that senior military officers think the U.S. troops deployed in the Saudi desert will not be ready to attack Iraqi forces by Jan. 15 - the deadline set by the United Nations for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait. That opinion was first expressed several days ago by Lt. Gen. Calvin Waller, deputy U.S. commander in Saudi Arabia. Cheney and Powell told Bush that commanders in the field predict U.S. troops won't be ready until the beginning or middle of February, The New York Times reported Tuesday. Hart had no comment on the report. The U.N. Security Council decided last month that the United States and its allies would be allowed to use force against Iraq unless its troops left Kuwait by Jan. 15. Bush said he wanted to give diplomacy one final chance by sending Secretary of State James Baker to Baghdad to convey American determination to implement the U.N. resolution. But attempts to arrange a meeting between Baker and Saddam have failed. And Baker, who said he would be willing to fly to Baghdad on Christmas day, was instead spending the holiday in Houston, his hometown. Cheney was spending Christmas in Wyoming and Vice President Dan Quayle was skiing in Vail, Colo. Quayle plans to visit American troops in Saudi Arabia on Dec. 29.

DOC.HEAD: Police Hope Ammo Sale Ban Will Reduce New Year's Gunfire
DOC.TEXT: A weeklong ban on ammunition sales that began Tuesday should make it harder to start 1991 with a bang, say authorities concerned about revelers shooting into the air New Year's Eve. The ban, in effect in San Fernando as well as Los Angeles, angers gun shop owners, who predict it will be ineffective. Barry Kahn, general manager of B&B Sales in North Hollywood, said customers will only have to visit a neighboring community to buy ammunition. ``Frankly, it's a crock,'' he said. ``They can't come up with the statistics to back the law.'' No one was injured last year by falling bullets, but in previous years bystanders have been wounded or even killed. ``We don't expect to solve it overnight, even with the ban,'' said police Deputy Chief William Rathburn. ``But we're optimistic that over the years we can stop the practice of celebrating New Year's Eve by firing guns.''

Communists Trounce Opposition in Serbia
DOC.TEXT: Serbia's renamed Communists overwhelmingly won the republic's first free vote in five decades, taking 194 seats in the republic's 250-seat parliament, according to final official results Tuesday. Serbia, the largest republic, and Montenegro, the smallest, were the only two of Yugoslavia's six republics to elect Commnunist governments. In the other four regions, center-right or nationalist parties triumphed. The results in Serbia and Montenegro threaten to push Yugoslavia one step closer to disintegration. The pro-capitalist opposition in Serbia did better in Sunday's second-round voting than in the first round Dec. 9. But it failed to dislodge the former Communists - recently renamed the Socialists - from control of the state assembly. In the first round, the Socialists won 87 seats and their leader, Slobodan Milosevic, was re-elected by a wide margin as the republic's president. The opposition, which formed a coalition on the eve of the second round ballot, won 48 seats in the one-chamber parliament. Eight seats went to independent candidates not involved in the coalition. Some prominent Communists and close allies of Milosevic, including Serbian Premier Stanko Radmilovic, were ousted in the second round. Dragoljub Micunovic of the Democratic Party, who defeated a Socialist candidate in Belgrade, told reporters the opposition should look into alleged irregularities before declaring the elections fair and honest. He also complained the opposition did not get enough coverage by Socialist-controlled media to present an effective campaign. In Slovenia, where a center-right coalition ousted Communists in spring elections, 95 percent of voters in a referendum Sunday chose independence from Yugoslavia. Slovenia's parliament will decide within the next six months whether to secede from the fractious federation. Both Slovenia and its Western-minded ally Croatia say they will secede if Yugoslavia is not transformed into a loose confederation. Serbia, home to 40 percent of Yugoslavia's 23.5 million inhabitants, advocates a strong federal government. Milosevic has not been willing to negotiate with the western republics and warned he will not respect borders within Yugoslavia if the federation breaks up. Yugoslavia's defense minister, Gen. Veljko Kadijevic, this month threatened army intervention to preserve federal integrity. A recent CIA report predicted the country could fall apart within 18 months because of ethnic tensions and political infighting among republics. It said civil war was possible.

DOC.HEAD: What Do You Get When You Cross a Potato with an Ear of Corn?
DOC.TEXT: Did you hear the one about the guy who thought he accepted a job in Iowa, only to find out Boise is in Idaho? Or the one about a Wall Street Journal real estate ad listing a $450,000 log cabin in Sun Valley, Iowa? The renowned ski resort is in Idaho. For a decade, Tim Woodward, a columnist for The Idaho Statesman, has written periodically about the confusion over two states 1,500 miles apart. Woodward says he keeps writing what he intends to be the last column on the subject, only to be deluged with newspaper clippings, magazine articles and testimonials from readers with more tales of what he calls the ``Idaho-Iowa connection.'' ``I have a file - it probably weighs about five pounds - of stuff that I still have to use,'' Woodward said. ``There isn't a week that goes by that I don't get things from people.'' Woodward, a 42-year-old Boise native who is writing a book on such mixups, believes much of the confusion comes what he calls ``the `I' factor.'' ``People think all four of the `I' states should be in a neat line in the Midwest,'' he said. Of course, three of them are: Iowa, Illinois and Indiana. The confusion between Iowa and Idaho certainly can't be attributed to a similarity of landscape. Idaho has a dozen national forests and its highest point is 12,662 feet; Iowa has no national forests and its highest point is 1,670 feet. ``We both have corn fields, but Iowa has a lot more,'' Woodward said. Woodward said one of his favorite mix-ups is the pilot who thought he was moving to Iowa. ``Someone told him the Boise assignment was a good one - that itwas good working hours, easy flying conditions, not much air traffic,'' Woodward said. ``Not until he actually got ready to move and had been given the Boise assignment did he realize he was 1,500 miles off,'' Woodward said. ``He had Boise and Des Moines mixed up.'' ``But he came anyway, he liked it, and he's still here.''

DOC.TEXT: Here are the ingredients of Christmas meals served to the 300,000 American military personnel who are part of Operation Desert Shield: --- In all, 35,000 pounds of shrimp; 150,000 pounds of rolled turkey and 4,000 whole turkeys; 108,000 pounds of canned ham; 172,000 pounds of roast beef; cranberry sauce; stuffing; mashed potatoes and sweet potatoes; mixed vegetables; fresh salad of lettuce, tomatoes and cucumbers; assorted breads; 35,000 pounds of fruitcake; 150,000 pumpkin, apple, peach, cherry or pecan pies; hard candy; mixed nuts; coffee, tea, milk and egg nog; soft drinks; apples, oranges, grapes, tangerines and pears; and 500,000 Mars and Snickers candy bars donated by the Saudis.

DOC.HEAD: For This Family, There's No Line to the Power Company
DOC.TEXT: When electric rates go up or the wind knocks power lines down, Norman Pearson and Julieanne Belanger never notice. Pearson and Belanger choose to live without any help from the electric company. They heat their home with wood and cook with propane or on a wood stove, depending on the season. Until last spring, when Pearson installed solar panels on his roof that provide some electricity, the only indoor lighting was from gas lamps, kerosene lanterns and flashlights. The couple do without indoor plumbing and use an outhouse 20 yards from their home. Pearson, who grew up in a middle-class home in a Chicago suburb, says he enjoys the feeling of self-sufficiency. His decision to go without electricity also reflects his opposition to nuclear power and concern that extending power lines to his house might encourage people to build on undeveloped property nearby. ``I've seen power bills,'' said Pearson. ``I'm amazed at how much they are.'' ``It's a secure thing,'' said Belanger, who built a tiny house of her own in nearby Concord with no water or electricity in the 1970s. ``Our neighbors sometimes would call after a storm and say, `Did you lose your electricity?' They'd forget.'' Pearson and Belanger are not the only people in Maine who live without electricity. There are houses scattered around the state without power, although there are no statistics on how many. The couple's house looks as if it were built in sections as needed. There are no visible wires leading to the house; the phone line is underground. Inside, the house is heated by a wood stove and the sun that shines through fiberglass covers on the southern side. Pearson cuts the wood on his land, primarily from damaged trees, to feed the stove. More than seven cords of wood - enough to last more than a year - are stacked in a shed. ``It's a great feeling to have excess wood,'' Pearson said. The couple cook on a big cast-iron wood-burning stove. During the summer they use a small stove hooked up to a propane gas tank. Their tiny refrigerator is powered by propane in the summer and is not used in the winter. The only water inside comes through a hand pump in the kitchen sink hooked up to a well. There's no toilet, no shower, no hot water except for the pot on top of the stove. Pearson said he could build a bathroom, but prefers the outhouse. Toilets waste too much clean water, he says. Pearson grew up with the typical amenities and graduated from Northwestern University. He was a Maine social worker for seven years and now works six to eight weeks a year as a substitute rural mail carrier. He is also a New Vineyard selectman. Belanger teaches first grade in New Portland, 10 miles away. Her daughter, Ahmen, is an eighth-grader at Mount Blue Junior High School in Farmington. Ahmen would prefer to live in a normal house with electricity and water. She said she would love to have a shower in the mornings, and isn't fond of having to walk to the outhouse, especially on cold winter nights. Many of her friends think the house is novel, but others refuse to visit overnight because there's no bathroom. Pearson said his lifestyle has surprised foreign friends who have visited the house over the years. ``They were amazed,'' Pearson said. ``They always thought America is the land of consumption, the land of plenty.''

DOC.HEAD: People in the News

DOC.TEXT: Singer Lou Rawls says his graduation from the College of Hard Knocks has made him determined that young black Americans will not be denied a higher education because they can't afford one. He is heading his 11th annual Parade of Stars Telethon for the United Negro College Fund on Saturday. The telethon has raised more than $77 million for 41 private, predominantly black colleges and universities. Rawls, a four-time Grammy Award-winner, occasionally runs across young people his telethon has aided. ``This young pharmacist kept staring at me,'' Rawls recounted recently. ``Finally, I asked her if something was wrong. She said, `I never thought I'd get a chance to thank you.' She told me she'd received her education with the help of the telethon. ``You can't put a price tag on experiences like that.'' Rawls, who grew up poor on Chicago's South Side, criticizes federal education policies, which have restricted minority-only scholarships. ``They play with education like it's a ball game,'' he said. ``How can they be so casual and so nonchalant about our education and our welfare?'' --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - The canceled TV series ``Baywatch,'' the lifeguard drama starring David Hasselhoff that drowned in low ratings, is riding a new wave of popularity overseas and will resume production next year, its syndicator said. ``Baywatch'' was canceled by NBC last spring after ending its first season ranked 74th among 111 series the three major networks. But the show proved a hit overseas, becoming the No. 1 imported show in the United Kingdom, said Henry Siegel, president of LBS Communications, which syndicates the show. The show has been sold in more than 40 nations. ``In the U.K., their rationale is that `Baywatch' may be what people perceive that the U.S. is all about. It has good-looking people with good action,'' said Siegel. The strong foreign sales make new episodes possible. Additionally, Hasselhoff has agreed to take a lower-than-usual salary in exchange for a share of the profits, Siegel said. Critics said the show lacked substance and had too many scantily clad beach romps - sort of a ``Babes Watch.'' But Siegel cited poor promotion as the reason ``Baywatch'' failed. Far from being a sexploitation show, he said, it's ```Emergency' on the beach. It's also an issue-oriented show, but the issues happen on the beach.'' Siegel expects the former cast to return, with the exception of Parker Stevenson and Shawn Weatherly. --- SACRAMENTO, Calif. (AP) - Wayne Newton will headline Gov.-elect Pete Wilson's inaugural party next month. The Las Vegas entertainer was invited by his friend and high school classmate, Gayle Wilson, the wife of the Republican senator who will be sworn in Jan. 7 as California's 36th governor. The party Jan. 6 at the Arco Arena in Sacramento will feature a stage show with actors Charlton Heston and Arnold Schwarzenegger, and the host will be Mary Hart of television's ``Entertainment Tonight,'' Wilson's office said. All three were active Wilson supporters during his campaign, Wilson spokesman Dan Schnur said. Also performing will be opera singer Julia Migenes, the Kingston Trio and comedians Fred Travalena and Gallagher. The gala, with tickets starting at $100, is privately funded. At Gov. George Deukmejian's gala celebrating his 1982 election, MGM produced a two-hour stage show that featured Dean Martin, Peggy Lee and Les Brown. --- MANILA, Philippines (AP) - Exiled former first lady Imelda Marcos said Tuesday that if the Philippine government allows her to come home, every day will be Christmas. ``I do hope that one day I will be allowed by the government of the Republic of the Philippines to give and love my countrymen freely,'' Mrs. Marcos said in a holiday message sent to news organizations here. ``You can be sure that with your former first lady, former Mother of the Country, when I come home, Christmas will not be for a day,'' she added. ``I will make it Christmas every day and make every day a day of giving and a day of love.'' The government refused to allow the late President Ferdinand Marcos and his family to return from Hawaii, where they fled when he was ousted in a popular uprising in 1986. Marcos died in September 1989. His successor, President Corazon Aquino, has said the sufferings of the Filipino people were caused in large part because Marcos and his associates looted the treasury of billions of dollars during his 20-year rule.

DOC.HEAD: All Quiet on N.H. Primary Front
DOC.TEXT: By this point on the political calendar, New Hampshire's campaign veterans are accustomed to seeing would-be presidential nominees at work in the first primary state, in person or by proxy. But a year before first primary of the next presidential election campaign, nothing is stirring. A few potential candidates visited in 1989 and early 1990, but not one candidate or campaign worker has set up shop in what should be prime time to prepare for 1992. ``It's been amazingly quiet,'' says Dennis Murphy, chairman of Illinois Sen. Paul Simon's 1988 primary campaign. ``I haven't heard from anyone, haven't talked to anyone even remotely representing a presidential candidate.'' By contrast, Democrats Bruce Babbitt, the former Arizona governor, and Rep. Richard A. Gephardt, the House majority leader from Missouri, campaigned in New Hampshire two years before the 1988 primary. Other candidates, including then-Vice President George Bush, had campaign workers in the state at this time in 1986. Bush and Massachusetts Gov. Michael S. Dukakis, the eventual nominees, won their party primaries here in 1988. Since the current primary system was instituted, no president has been elected without winning in New Hampshire first. In Iowa, site of the first presidential caucus, the political scene is equally quiet. What's the story? Some say candidates have abandoned long primary campaigns because they are too grueling, can lead to burnout, and have turned off many voters. They also point to Gephardt, who withdrew before the national convention in 1988, as evidence that candidates who get the jump on their competition often end up losing anyway. Others say candidates don't want to tip their hands too early. ``After even one trip here, no one can say anything on their minds anymore because it will be viewed as being motivated by presidential politics,'' says Ned Helms, the state Democratic chairman. Sen. Sam Nunn of Georgia recently turned down an invitation to speak in New Hampshire in February. ``I am not ready to have everyone in the country say that Sam Nunn has decided to run for president,'' he explained. The 1988 primary was for an open presidential race, with Ronald Reagan retiring. Bush will be up for re-election in 1992. State Republican Chairwoman Rhona Charbonneau said Gov. Mario Cuomo's narrowed margin in a three-way New York election, and Sen. Bill Bradley's close call victory in New Jersey hurt two of the Democrats' most appealing potential candidates. Other Democrats mentioned as possible entries include Nunn; Sens. Joseph R. Biden of Delaware, Lloyd M. Bentsen of Texas, Albert Gore Jr. of Tennessee, Tom Harkin of Iowa and Bob Kerrey of Nebraska; Govs. Douglas Wilder of Virginia and Richard Celeste of Ohio; and the Rev. Jesse Jackson. The speculation about a possible conservative challenge to Bush in a Republican primary comes up short of likely candidates. Former Delaware Gov. Pete du Pont has set up a political action committee, but he quickly told a New Hampshire newspaper that it wasn't to finance a second presidential bid. Du Pont ran in 1988. He said his Committee for Republican Leadership is to fight tax increases, not to launch a presidential bid. Thomas Rath, who led Sen. Bob Dole's 1988 New Hampshire primary effort, says Bush's enormous popularity for most of his first term, and the Persian Gulf crisis, are reasons for the political inactivity. ``For an extended period of time Bush's numbers were so high, they maybe scared off challengers,'' Rath says. ``And the Middle East has had a big impact. I don't think anyone wants to look like they're using it for their own political gain.'' Some welcome the change from two-year primary campaigns. `I'm not disappointed at all,'' Murphy says. ``I've never been a fan of the first-in-the-nation primary. What happens in the statehouse is much more important.'' Mary Chambers, Democratic leader of the New Hampshire House, also believes less is better in primary elections. ``Nobody is even thinking about it - they're too busy with other things,'' she says. ``They are going to stay (in Washington) and take care of business as long as it's so questionable about what will happen in the Middle East.''

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Demand Democratic Reforms, Release of Dissident
DOC.TEXT: About 12,000 demonstrators marched through the streets Tuesday to demand swifter democratic reforms and the release of a dissident leader jailed for promoting Taiwan independence. The demonstration was organized by the Democratic Progressive Party, the main opposition to the governing Nationalist Party, which lost a civil war to the Communists in 1949 and retreated to Taiwan. Carrying chrysanthemums to symbolize a peaceful protest, the demonstrators chanted ``(We want) independent sovereignty and constitutional democracy!'' and ``Huang Hwa is not guilty!'' Huang, 51, an opposition leader, was convicted of sedition earlier this month. He was sentenced to 10 years imprisonment for advocating independence for Taiwan and raising funds to topple the Nationalist government. The demonstration ended after three hours at a memorial park where opposition leaders criticized the government for failing to move faster on democratic reforms. About 2,000 policemen guarded the mile-long route taken by the demonstrators, but officials reported no incidents. Most of the demonstrators were supporters of the Democratic Progressive Party, students, and professors. Earlier Tuesday, the party's eight members in the National Assembly, Taiwan's electoral college, walked out in protest shortly before President Lee Teng-hui delivered a speech promising to modernize Taiwan's constitution. He also said he would end before May a state of war declared against the rival Communist Chinese in 1948. The state of war included the suspension of certain constitutional rights. Outside the National Assembly, about 100 students clashed briefly with policemen who prevented them from entering the building. The officers later agreed to allow a delegation to present a petition. The National Assembly met for Constitution Day. In his address, Lee said the government would propose amendments to the constitution, which was enacted in 1937, and that all Assembly members would be involved in the revisions. He said he hoped a new constitution would be ready by mid-1992.

DOC.HEAD: Former U.S. Envoy To Soviet Union Dead At 82
DOC.TEXT: Foy David Kohler, a career diplomat and the U.S. ambassador to Moscow during the height of the Cold War, has died at age 82. Kohler, who was present for the 1959 ``kitchen debate'' between Soviet leader Nikita Khrushchev and then-Vice President Richard Nixon, died Sunday at Jupiter Hospital. His home was in Juno Beach. ``His loss is a great loss,'' said former Secretary of State Dean Rusk. ``Foy Kohler was one of our greatest professional diplomats. He was a lifelong member of the foreign service. He served with great distinction.'' Kohler was ambassador to the Soviet Union from August 1962 to November 1966. He was considered a member of the realist school of international politics, which emphasized the importance of military, economic and political power in world affairs. Kohler took his first post as vice consul in Windsor, Ontario, in 1931. Later assignments took him to Romania, Yugoslavia, Greece, Egypt, England and Turkey. He also toured Vietnam, Pakistan and Bolivia on fact-finding missions for U.S. aid programs, and he served as director of the Voice of America. From 1941 to 1945 he served as assistant chief of the State Department's Division of Near Eastern Affairs. Kohler first went to Moscow in January 1947 as first secretary of the U.S. Embassy. He was there when Khrushchev and Nixon toured a model American kitchen during a 1959 American exposition in Moscow. Khrushchev became angry, and the ``kitchen debate'' between him and Nixon drew international attention. President John F. Kennedy tapped the Russian-speaking diplomat - then assistant secretary of state for European affairs - to become ambassador to the Soviet Union in 1962. Shortly after he arrived in Moscow in his new post, the Cuban missile crisis erupted and brought the world to the brink of war. Nonetheless, Kohler respected Khrushchev. ``You couldn't help but like him just as an individual,'' he once said. ``He was a shrewd peasant and he loved to trade repartee. He had a quick wit. It's true that Khrushchev - especially with his de-Stalinization speech - shook up the society and greatly eased the terror that had prevailed under Stalin. On the other hand, Khrushchev was a true believer in Bolshevism.'' After leaving Moscow, Kohler was undersecretary of state for political affairs for a year. He retired in 1967 and then spent almost 11 years as a professor at the University of Miami's graduate center for Advanced International Studies. The hospital said Tuedsday that Kohler died after a long illness but did not release details. He is survived by his wife, Phyllis. Funeral arrangements were pending.

DOC.HEAD: Fellow Workers Sacrifice Pay To Save Jobs of Colleagues in NY Agency
DOC.TEXT: Five employees of a state tax agency are going to get to keep their jobs thanks to the cooperation of their fellow workers. The five employees of the Board of Equalization and Assessment were expected to be among the nearly 2,000 state workers being laid off to help combat a $1 billion budget deficit in New York state. But their colleagues saved their jobs by volunteering to take some time off without pay, making the agency's budget stretch a little further, Ramon Rodriguez, assistant director of the board, said Monday. The board oversees the local administration of property taxes. ``The holiday season probably had something to do with the good spirit, but my sense is we're an agency that would do this any time of the year,'' he added. Employees at the agency approached managers and asked that they survey the staff to see who would be willing to give up a few days pay to save jobs, he said. A notice went out to all employees last week. In all, 279 of the board's 560 employees agreed to take one to three days off without pay. ``What you have is an agency coming together as a community,'' said Rodriguez. That wasn't the only example of job-saving at the board. Eleven management-level workers saved two other employees' jobs by volunteering to give up a week of vacation pay. Despite such actions, the board didn't completely avoid layoffs. Rodriguez said two employees are taking early retirement and three others will have to be laid off.

DOC.HEAD: Feds Turn to Big Game Poachers for Help in Detering Illegal Hunting
DOC.TEXT: Federal wildlife agents are using a new weapon in their battle against big game poachers - the poachers themselves. A U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service program is turning convicted poachers into video preachers. Violators tell fellow hunters and hunting guides about the impact of the illegal killing of grizzlies, wolves, caribou, Dall sheep, elk and other big game and waterfowl in Alaska and the West. One of the biggest guns among the new anti-poaching crusaders is longtime Alaska guide and outfitter Ron Hayes. Hayes, who was convicted in 1987 of illegally hunting grizzly bears by airplane, served two years in prison, forfeited several aircraft, paid thousands of dollars in fines and lost his hunting privilege. ``He was probably the most notorious bandit guide that ever lived,'' said Dave Hall, a New Orleans-based agent of the Fish and Wildlife Service who is organizing the video project. Hall visited Hayes several times in prison, and helped show him of the error of his ways. On Hall's urging, Hayes agreed to help make a 30-minute video last summer for the service's use and to cooperate with a National Geographic Society television documentary on poaching to be broadcast this spring. Several other convicted poachers have agreed to appear in the agency's videos. ``This is the only way we can make conservation enforcement effective,'' Hall said. Alaska has 54.5 million acres of national park lands and just 11 patrol rangers. That comes to nearly 5 million acres per ranger. The National Parks and Conservation Association and some wildlife officials contend poaching harms big game species by depleting the strongest animals in the species, reducing the quality of the gene pool. Other officials say there is not enough biological evidence to support that conclusion. Hall has put his emphasis on guides because Alaska prohibits non-residents from hunting big game without the services of one of the approximately 450 guide-outfitters in the state. For the National Geographic Society project filmed during the summer, Hayes re-created his poaching technique on the Katmai National Park and Preserve by herding a grizzly to a hunting party with his airplane. In a startling admission, Hayes said in the film that of the 37 grizzlies he helped hunters place in the Boone and Crockett Club's record book, every one was shot after being herded illegally to the hunter with an airplane. The National Geographic film will be broadcast this spring as one of four segments on poaching in its ``Explorer'' series. Other segments will deal with poaching of waterfowl and elk and a national overview of the problem. Because of Alaska's size and the number of trophy animals hunted, poaching in the state has become a major problem, officials said. There are no figures for the number of animals killed illegally. But state wildlife officials say hunters come to Alaska from around the world seeking trophy-sized sheep, grizzlies and wolves and to hunt moose and caribou, black bear, waterfowl and other game animals. Not all poaching is for sport. Some hunters illegally kill big game animals for selected body parts. Bear gall bladders are used in some Asian cultures for medical purposes, bear claws are used to make jewelry, and caribou antlers are ground up to make powdered potions said to enhance sex. Federal and state officials, however, said they are most concerned about trophy poachers. The guides are under great pressure to produce trophy animals - and have a huge financial stake in hunters' success. Guides get paid on a per-animal basis, and can receive $7,000 or more for a Dall sheep and between $8,000 and $10,000 for a grizzly, according to Jim Hannah, a National Park Service district ranger in the 13 million-acre Wrangell-St. Elias National Park and Preserve.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf Allies Urge Saddam to Give Up Kuwait
DOC.TEXT: King Fahd of Saudi Arabia and his partners in the six-nation Gulf Cooperation Council urged Saddam Hussein on Tuesday to withdraw from Kuwait and spare Iraq the horrors of war. The leaders wound up a four-day summit by insisting anew that Iraq reinstate the exiled al-Sabah family as rulers of Kuwait and withdraw from the emirate unconditionally before the Jan. 15 deadline set by the United Nations Security Council. They also demanded that Iraq pay reparations and compensation to Kuwait and its citizens for losses suffered because of the invasion. ``The council affirmed that all member countries, governments and peoples stand solidly with the people of Kuwait until its complete liberation,'' said a communique read by the group's secretary-general, Abdullah Bishara. The leaders of Saudi Arabia, Kuwait, Qatar, Bahrain, Oman and the United Arab Emirates affirmed the ``right and determination'' of the gulf allies to ``resort to all means to guarantee restoration of sovereignty and legitimacy'' to Kuwait. The emir of Kuwait, Sheik Jaber al-Sabah, expressed gratitude to the allies and said he would look forward the next summit in liberated Kuwait. The summit's communique denounced Iraq for the invasion of Kuwait, saying it had ``put the entire region on the brink of a destructive war.'' Summit leaders stressed the need for ensuring future regional security through joint efforts with gulf powers and other Arab and international powers. Sheik Nawaf al-Ahmed, defense minister in Kuwait's Saudi-based government-in-exile, had indicated earlier that the summit would consider the advisibility of asking the United States and some Arab powers to station troops in Kuwait if it were liberated. Summit leaders pledged unspecified economic assistance to Arab and Islamic countries that have supported Saudi Arabia's call for the multinational force to stand up to Saddam. Proposals by defense ministers for enhancing the military potential of the Gulf Cooperation Council member states were ratified, the communique said. It gave no details. The Cooperation Council leaders had discussed bolstering their joint defenses, which had been inadequate to counter Iraq's Aug. 2 sweep through Kuwait despite heavy spending on advanced weapons systems and other hardware over the last decade. Sources speaking on condition of anonymity said that among the plans discussed was building up the organization's rapid deployment Peninsula Shield force from 10,000 to 50,000 men. Officials also said leaders decided to include Iran in their planned contacts on long-range security strategy arrangements. The Cooperation Council countries had sided with Iraq against Iran in the two nations' eight-year war.

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Jews on Soviet Jews: Israel Must Do Better
DOC.TEXT: Some American Jewish leaders Tuesday criticized Israel's performance so far in handling the influx of Soviet Jewish immigrants. ``We are concerned that there is no sense of urgency,'' Seymour Reich, outgoing chairman of the Conference of Presidents of Major American Jewish Organizations, told a news conference. ``We believe it is incumbent on Israel to address this as a top priority, using all of its resources, all of its people, all of its government facilities,'' he said. About 172,000 Soviet Jews have settled in Israel this year, and officials expect 1 million by the end of 1992. But efforts to absorb them have run into bureaucratic and financial difficulties. Shoshana Cardin, the newly elected chairman of the New York-based conference, the leading U.S. Jewish organization, said there appeared to be a lack of coordination among ministries dealing with immigrant absorption. Housing Minister Ariel Sharon is at odds with Absorption Minister Yitzhak Peretz and has accused Peretz's staff of failing to cope with the influx. Peretz is boycotting the Cabinet immigration committee headed by Sharon. ``There seems to be not that urgency of everyone working together to ensure the maximum efficiency in the minimum amount of time,'' Crdin said. She said, ``That sense of urgency will translate itself in the diaspora'' of Jewish communities outside Israel, and encourage fund raising and investment in this country. Peretz, a rabbi, has made hotly disputed claims that up to 35 percent of the Soviet immigrants are not Jewish. Other rabbis in the government say the figure is no more than 5 percent. Peretz says Israel should tighten its Law of Return, which affords automatic citizenship to all Jewish immigrants. Asked to comment, Cardin said: ``Anything that would deny or impede the aliya (immigration) would be tragic at this point.''

DOC.HEAD: Tamil Tiger Rebels Offer Short New Year's Truce
