DOC.TEXT: A Christmas Day fire that may have been ignited by a smoldering cigarette killed five people, including two children, police said. Arson experts helped investigate, but fire Capt. Bruce Sutton said firefighters ``have no reason to believe it was anything but an accident.'' ``We believe it was caused by a smoldering cigarette, but we took all kinds of samples from the house and have sent them to the lab,'' Sutton said. He said it would be at least Thursday before the lab report was completed. The early morning fire apparently started at the end of a couch on the first floor of the 2{-story brick house, and caused $30,000 damage, he said. A visitor to the home, Todd Allen Qualls, 29, of Columbus, said he awakened to the smell of smoke and escaped through a window, cutting his bare feet on glass. He said he climbed down a ladder put up by firefighters. ``It all happened so fast, I don't really know what happened,'' Qualls said. Family members said the victims were India Hamrick, 25; Ronina Hamrick, 30; Gerald Givens, 39; Rashawn Hamrick, 4; and Natasha Hamrick, 10, all of whom lived in the house that burned. India and Ronina Hamrick were sisters, Ronina was the mother of the two children, and Givens was the former husband of India and Ronina Hamrick's mother, according to India and Ronina's brother, Greg Hamrick, and their aunt, Jeane Bell. One firefighter was injured slightly.

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Calls for `Liberation' of Palestine
With AM-Gulf-Christmas
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein, declaring America the source of all evil in the Mideast, reiterated his claim that Kuwait is part of Iraq and said Tuesday that Palestine, not Kuwait, needed to be ``liberated.'' Speaking only 21 days before the U.N. deadline for his troops to leave Kuwait, Saddam suggested to visiting Jordanian politicians he wouldn't leave Kuwait until Israel withdrew from the occupied territories. ``Let all the fleets and Israel hear, Palestine comes first and it must be liberated,'' Saddam said in a speech broadcast on Iraqi state radio. The Iraqi president also repeated his claim that Kuwait was unjustly removed from Baghdad's rule by British colonial rulers. He challenged the United States, Britain, and other forces massing in the Persian Gulf region to put the question of Kuwait's future to an Arab referendum: ``If you brought your fleets because of this issue, how can you help the people in Kuwait have their say in a democratic manner? ... ``Why do they not hold a referendum to see the inclination of the majority of the Arab people, if they are truly democratic?'' Saddam said. He denounced ``the United States and its allies on the international level; that is, all elements of evil, hatred, and deviation, as well as its agents in the Arab homeland.'' That was evidently a reference to Saudi Arabia, Egypt, Syria, Morocco and other Arab nations among the U.S.-dominated multinational force of some 400,000 troops preparing for the Jan. 15 deadline for Iraq's withdrawal. The U.N. Security Council have given Baghdad until that date to unconditionally pull out of Kuwait, which it conquered on Aug. 2, and restore the government of the emir of Kuwait. After Jan. 15, the Security Council said, the allies of Kuwait's government-in-exile may use any means necessary, including military force, to liberate the emirate.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Killed in New York City in Eight Hours Christmas Eve and Morning
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS grafs 6-7 pvs `Another pair...' with 2 grafs UPDATING with details of one shooting, two men arrested; SUBS penultimate graf with 1 graf to note second man wounded at party.
DOC.TEXT: Homicide didn't take a holiday in the nation's largest city as eight people were killed in as many hours Christmas Eve and morning. The victims included a mother who died after she allegedly was punched in the face by her son at a holiday gathering, a man who was fatally shot as he carried holiday packages to his home, and a toddler whose mother was charged with homicide, police said Tuesday. Maria Martinez, 67, died at a local hospital after her son, Heriberto Altreche, 37, allegedly hit her during a family get-together in the Bronx Monday night, police Sgt. Tina Mohrmann said. The medical examiner was to determine if the punch caused her death, Mohrmann said. The toddler, 20-month-old Belinda Jackson, died Monday night at the Bronx hospital where she was brought suffering from apparant multiple trauma. The mother, Ruby Jackson, was charged with homicide and her other five children were turned over to child welfare authorities. Andre Rodriguez, 18, was fatally shot Monday night as he fled two men who began shooting at him while he stood on a street corner near his home in the Bronx, Mohrmann said. Another pair of men, armed with shotguns, confronted Berhane Waldermarian, 31, in fron of his Queens home and announced a robbery. Waldermarian, who was carrying holiday gifts, put his packages down on the sidewalk. The gunmen shot him once in the stomach and fled empty-handed. Waldermarian's parents, wife and children were inside the house. Waldermarian was taken to a hospital, where he died Tuesday morning. Anthony Mack, 18, and Vernon Ricks, 24, both of Queens, were charged with second-degree murder in Waldermarian's death, said Sgt. Mary Wrensen, a police spokeswoman. The body of a man who had been shot in the head was found slumped over the steering wheel of a car in Brooklyn Monday evening. Elsewhere in Brooklyn, a Christmas Eve shopper shot and killed one man and critically injured a second who were trying to rob a furniture store and its patrons. None of the customers or employees was injured. An unidentified 34-year-old was shot and killed early Tuesday after he got involved in a dispute at a Bronx Christmas party. A 28-year-old man standing nearby was wounded from a shot in the chest, Mohrmann said. Also on Tuesday morning, police found the body of a man, apparently in his mid-20s, who had been shot in the back and buttocks and left on a Brooklyn street, Mohrmann said. The man was shot during an apparent robbery.

DOC.HEAD: Prison Parolees Charged in Cabin Slayings Took Women as `Shields'
DOC.TEXT: Two prison parolees charged with fatally shooting two women and trying to kill a man at a remote mountain cabin had kidnapped the man's daughters to use as shields if confronted by police, court records said. The killings and kidnappings occurred Saturday when a family from Humble, Texas, surprised two men apparently burglarzing the cabin where they were to spend the holidays, authorities said. The cabin is in the Summit Count community of Oakley and is only reachable by snowmobile. The men, Von Lester Taylor, 25, and Edward Steven Deli, 21, were arraigned Monday before 3rd Circuit Judge Floyd Gowans on two counts each of first-degree murder and two counts of aggravated kidnapping. They also were charged with one count each of attempted first-degree murder, aggravated arson, theft, aggravated assault, aggravated robbery and failure to respond to an officer's signal to stop. Both were held without bail in Summit County Jail pending a Jan. 8 preliminary hearing. Kaye Tidwell Tiede, 51, and her mother, Beth Harmon Tidwell Potts, who was in her mid-70s, were shot by two men who confronted them when they arrived at the cabin Saturday. Mrs. Tiede's daughter, Linae, 20, was tied up. Mrs. Tiede's husband, Rolf, was shot and wounded when he and their daughter Tricia, 16, arrived at the cabin several hours later. He was released from University Hospital on Monday. The men took Tricia and Linae Tiede to use as shields in case police confronted them, court documents said. The sisters were unharmed. Before leaving, the men poured snowmobile fuel throughout the two-story cabin and started a fire that caused substantial damage to the upper floor. The men forced the sisters onto snowmobiles and they traveled about two miles to the Tiede family car. The four got into the car, and were spotted by authorities on a nearby highway soon afterward. The men surrendered after a police chase that reached speeds of up to 100 mph. Deli and Taylor left a Salt Lake City halfway house on Dec. 14 to look for jobs and never returned. Taylor was paroled to the Community Corrections Center on Oct. 23 after serving a sentence for aggravated burglary, a state corrections spokesman said. Deli was convicted of aggravated arson and was paroled to the halfway house on Nov. 27.

DOC.HEAD: Santa's `Sleigh' Impounded
DOC.TEXT: Santa Claus got a parking ticket while delivering toys, jackets and food to needy families, and he says he may go to court over the $150 he had to pay to retrieve his ``sleigh.'' Larry Longfelder, a lawyer and president of the Forgotten Childrens' Fund, said he didn't know he was in an apartment manager's reserved space when he stopped at an apartment building dressed as Santa on Christmas Eve. Within 10 minutes, he said, the car's wheels had been locked to a barrel by an employee of the Community Police Traffic and Parking Enforcement Agency. ``Just because it's Santa Claus doesn't mean he can park anywhere,'' said a supervisor for the private agency, who instructed an employee to insist on the $150 fee before releasing the vehicle. The supervisor refused to give his name. Longfelder said the agency refused to accept a check or credit card, so he had to walk to an automatic teller machine and withdraw $150 before continuing his rounds. ``It's crazy to do this to Santa,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Relative Says Fire That Killed 7 Started By Lights On Tree
DOC.TEXT: A fire that killed a man and six of his nine children probably started when a light bulb on the Christmas tree overheated and sparked, a relative said. Initial reports from fire investigators said the tree fell over, broke a bulb and started the blaze. But John Dell'Orco said Monday the tree had been tied to the ceiling and couldn't have fallen over. Dell'Orco is the brother of Martin Dell'Orco, 38, who died in the Saturday fire along with his children Bonnie, 11; Sara, 9; Katie, 8; Megan and Michaelboth 5, and Robert, 4. Martin Dell'Orco's wife, Debbie, 36, had bought new Christmas lights for the tree and had noticed one of the bulbs was hot before she decorated the tree, John Dell'Orco said. But she and her husband dismissed it, he said. More than $20,000 has been donated to the Dell'Orcos from across the country, said Canton Township Sgt. Eddie Tanner. Apartments, clothing, food and funeral services also have been offered to the survivors.

DOC.HEAD: Security Agency Announces Arrest of 31 Revolutionary Students
DOC.TEXT: Security forces arrested 31 radical students and charged them with conspiring with North Korea to overthrow the government, the national intelligence agency said Wednesday. More than 70 other members of an undeground group called Chamintong are on a wanted list, the National Security Planning agency said. Chamintong means independence, democracy and unification. The agency said in a news release that Chamintong's goal was to form a unfified Korea by 1995 under North Korean leader Kim Il Sung's leadership, if necessary through an armed uprising in the South. The agency said that the 31 students were core members of Chamintong, which it said was formed in 1988 with guidance from a clandestine North Korean propaganda agency. Chamintong manipulated Chondaehyop, a dissident student alliance, to stage anti-government and anti-American activities in the name of seeking democratization, the news release said. Chondaehyop has been involved in sometimes violent demonstrations demanding the pullout of American troops and overthrow of the Seoul regime in favor of unification with the North. The 31 arrested students included Chondaehyop chairman Song Kap-suk, 24, a senior at Chonanm Unviersity in Kwangju, who was arrested in October. The agency did not say when the others were arrested. The agency said Chamintong members were obliged to pledge allegiance to Kim Il Sung and sing songs praising Kim's exploits fighting Japanese colonial rule, the agency said. Japan colonized Korea from 1910 through World War II. The peninsula was divided following the war and since the Korean War has been split into the staunchly Communist North, ruled by Kim, and the free market-oriented South, dominated by the military with increasingly democratic rule. The prime ministers of the Koreas have held three rounds of talks since September to ease hostilities and improve communication between their countries, but they have failed to make any tangible progress.

Soldiers and cautious visitors wandered through nearly deserted streets as fear of violence left Bethlehem with one of its smallest Christmas crowds in recent memory. ``For us, Christmas is an event of peace, and here you cannot feel peace,''said German tourist Gabriele Beitz in Manger Square, near the grotto where tradition holds that Christ was born. The Christmas mood elsewhere in the Middle East was also anxious as U.S. troops in the Persian Gulf were placed on a heightened state of alert to guard against terrorist attacks. But soldiers still managed to mark the holiday with carols, decorations and desert religious services. ---= FRESNO, Calif. (AP) - The worst freeze since 1937 devastated California's navel orange crop, sending growers into Christmas with little hope of salvaging the season's harvest. ``This is way worse than I've ever seen,'' Bakersfield-area grower John Slikker Jr. said Monday. ``Yesterday, we cut these oranges in half. ... It was just like cutting through a Popsicle.'' The weekend Arctic blast also damaged nursery plants, lemons and avocados and destroyed most early Southern California strawberries, agriculture officials said. Crop damage was put in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Cliff Holland of California Citrus Mutual, a growers organization, admitted the string of freezing nights probably destroyed the state's 1990-91 navel orange harvest. ---= NEW YORK (AP) - When all the receipts are tallied, Christmas sales are likely to be unchanged or barely above last year, a poor season for retailers who couldn't overcome consumer worries over the economy and Middle East. High-profile retailing companies around the country complained Monday their sales were a disappointment. DOC.HEAD: Bush Lends Presidential Clout To The A-Word
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Note language which quotes Bush warning that Saddam Hussein will ``get his ass kicked'' in military confrontation, and earlier Bush and Carter use of similar terms
DOC.HEAD: An AP News Analysis
DOC.TEXT: In the barracks or the locker room, nobody thinks twice about threatening to whip, kick or otherwise manhandle the opposition's rear end. It's different when presidents get down and graphic. That may make it an effective way to turn up the volume when the man in the White House doesn't think somebody is paying attention. As in President Bush's holiday message to Saddam Hussein: ``If we get into an armed situation, he's going to get his ass kicked.'' There are certain amenities about the purposeful, presidential use of such terminology for public consumption. It's not done on tape or on camera, except inadvertently. Better to have it relayed second hand, leaving just a little room for doubt that a leader so eminent would talk that way. And it can't be done often or it would become too ordinary to attract attention. Besides, there's always a risk of a backlash. A former governor of Massachusetts, Francis W. Sargent, once used the A-word at a governors conference, and said his mother called to tell him she was going to wash his mouth out with soap. Then again, it's hardly an X-rated term. And it is right there in the dictionary: ``Ass: (vulgar slang) the buttocks.'' Bush's latest usage was widely quoted on radio and television, and in print. After Bush met with a group of congressmen on Dec. 20, Rep. Elton Gallegly, R-Calif., said the president had told them that he doesn't think Saddam Hussein understands that there really will be war if he doesn't get out of Kuwait. ``The greatest potential for preventing any kind of an armed confrontation is to make sure that Saddam Hussein be made really aware that, to quote him, that `If we get into an armed situation, he's going to get his ass kicked','' Gallegly said. While others confirmed the remark, Bush was circumspect. Asked later whether it was an accurate quotation, the president arched his eyebrows and said nothing. He'd been more forthcoming after accidentally putting a similar observation on the record during the 1984 campaign, when he was vice president. ``We tried to kick a little ass last night,'' he said after a campaign debate with Rep. Geraldine A. Ferraro, his Democratic opponent. Bush made the comment while shaking hands with dockworkers at a campaign rally in New Jersey, unaware that there was a boom microphone close enough to pick up his words. Later on, he said he wasn't apologizing. ``I stand behind it. I use it all the time. My kids use it, everybody who competes in sports uses it.'' Ronald Reagan expressed some doubt about the campaign comment, saying he wasn't inclined to believe his vice president had said it. Reagan himself didn't go beyond ``keister,'' which is slang for ``rump.'' In 1983, irked that information about his budget and other White House business was finding its way into print, Reagan ordered a crackdown. ``I've had it up to my keister with these leaks,'' he told his staff. No such gentler euphemism would do for Jimmy Carter when Sen. Edward M. Kennedy was preparing to challenge him for the 1980 Democratic presidential nomination. ``If Kennedy runs, I'll whip his ass,'' Carter said at a White House dinner with Democratic congressmen. ``I was startled,'' said then-Rep. William M. Brodhead, D-Mich. ``I thought my ears were deceiving me. I said, `Excuse me, Mr. President, what did you say?' And Carter replied, `If Kennedy runs, I'll whip his ass.' '' He did and Carter did. But strong words aren't enough. Reagan won the White House. --- EDITOR'S NOTE - Walter R. Mears, vice president and columnist for The Associated Press, has reported on Washington and national politics for more than 25 years.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Up, Stocks Plunge
DOC.TEXT: The dollar rose against the yen and stock prices fell in sluggish trading in Tokyo Tuesday amid concerns about the Middle East and political problems in the Soviet Union. The dollar closed at 135.95 yen, up 0.25 yen from Friday's close of 135.70 yen. Financial markets were closed on Monday for a national holiday. After oening at 135.95 yen, the dollar ranged from 135.90 yen to 136.25 yen. Trading was quiet at $2.28 billion in spot transactions, down from $12.351 billion on Friday. The dollar has now gained 2.92 yen in four trading days. Market players were beginning to pay more attention to international politics than to interest rate shifts, said Tomoko Hirai, a dealer at Citibank. The U.S. Federal Reserve lowered a key interest rate last week, a move that is generally associated with the weaker dollar. But anxieties about the future of the Soviet Union following Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze's resignation announcement last week and the continuing tensions in the Middle East have been putting upward pressures on the dollar, dealers noted. Investors tend to buy the dollar as a safe haven in times of international uncertainty. ``The dollar is stable now, but there is a technical resistance point to its rise at 136.30 yen,'' said Hirai. On the stock exchange, the stronger dollar, lower bond prices and worries about the Persian Gulf and the Soviet Union helped push the Nikkei average lower, dealers said. The 225-issue Nikkei Stock Average closed at 23,767.88 points, down 351.72 points or 1.46 percent from Friday's close. Volume on the first section was estimated at a slim 210 million shares, down from 350.621 million Friday. The Nikkei average has now shed 1,108.90 points in three trading days. The absence of foreign investors slowed down trading, said a dealer at a Tokyo-based securities firm. Financial markets were closed overseas today for Christmas. In bond dealings, the price of benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 87.36 points from Friday's 87.78-point close. Their yield rose to 7.210 percent from 7.115 percent.

DOC.HEAD: If War Comes, How Will the Markets React?
DOC.TEXT: If the crisis in the Persian Gulf heats up, would U.S. securities and futures markets melt down? Probably not, say most market professionals, although they disagree on just how sharp a backlash there would be on exchange floors and trading pits. ``If you had the outbreak of a sudden, major shooting war in the Middle East, I suspect that short-term, the market would go into a freefall but I also wouldn't be surprised at all if it closed higher two or three days later,'' said Robert Kirby, chairman of Capital Guardian Trust Co. in Los Angeles. Yale Hirsch, a market tracker who produces the Stock Trader's Almanac, predicts ``if there's no shooting war or drawn-out impasse, we expect the Dow (Jones industrial average) to break through 3,000 in 1991.'' But if the crisis ends badly, the average, a key stock market indicator, could sink to 2,000 next year, he said. Federal regulators say they have contingency plans to head off panic in the markets - but what those plans are, they're not saying. The Securities and Exchange Commission, which oversees the stock, bond and mutual fund markets, says it has developed plans for emergencies and has been in contact with the exchanges. ``But we don't discuss specific situations or specific contingency plans,'' said Brandon Becker, associate director of the SEC's Market Regulation Division. Wendy Gramm, chairwoman of the Commodity Futures Trading Commission, who oversees futures markets for key commodities such as oil, has said the CFTC and other agencies have plans for dealing with market disruptions. But she also would not elaborate. A CFTC insider said officials have plans to get in touch with the exchanges to coordinate information among the various markets. But ``do we have a plan so that if X happens we'll do this? No. Because I think whatever X we put down, or Y or Z, there'd be Q, R and S on top of that. We don't have a plan in that sense and we just don't think we can,'' said the source, who spoke on condition of anonymity. The big question is whether the markets' reaction to bad news from the Gulf would be severe enough to force the exchanges or regulators to shut them down. CFTC Commissioner William Albrecht has said a market closing would be ``the last thing you really want to do'' because of the need to determine prices and keep trading flowing. The Chicago Mercantile Exchange has said it would stop trading stock index futures, futures contracts based on a range of stocks, if the New York Stock Exchange closed in the event of war. However, the NYSE also isn't revealing its hand. ``I'm not going to say there's a plan in place or not in place until you know what's been presented to you,'' said Richard Torrenzano, an NYSE spokesman. Even officials at the Merc decline to discuss the issue on the record, saying they didn't want to speculate on what they might do. NYSE officials point to a series of ``circuit-breakers'' created since the 1987 stock market crash that would slow down forms of computerized program trading - often blamed for worsening stock market volatility or temporarily halt trading if the market plunged or skyrocketed 250 or more points. Should there be a surge in buying, selling or volume ``these circuit breakers would serve to slow the market down and give everyone a chance to assess what has taken place and make an investment decision,'' said Torrenzano. Kirby, the Capital Guardian Trust chief and a member of the commission appointed by President Reagan to investigate the 1987 stock market crash, said a market halt ``is the only fair way to handle this kind of situation.'' But market shutdowns, except for the occasional power outage in New York or Chicago, are rare. The NYSE shut down at the beginning of World War I, from July 31 to Nov. 28, 1914. That was largely because of fears that gold-hungry Europe would sell its securities in New York and take gold home, sparking a possible economic collapse in this country, said stock market historian Robert Sobel of Hofstra University. The New York markets also shut for V-J Day at the end of World War II and after President Kennedy was assassinated. Sobel doesn't think there would be a panic if war broke out in the Gulf because ``this is an event that we can look ahead and think about. When it happens, people have plans all ready.'' By contrast, he said, the crash of 1987, when the Dow Jones industrial average plunged more than 500 points, ``caught a lot of people unaware..'' ``It's the ones that catch you unaware that cause panics,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Five Years After Big Bang, London Market Short of Potential
DOC.TEXT: Nearly five years after the ``Big Bang'' deregulation of Britain's financial markets, experts say London's pioneering electronic stock market isn't living up to its potential. Deregulation was supposed to sweep away London's clubby cartel of stock dealers and create a fast, accessible and bigger electronic market of the future. But critics say there aren't enough stock dealers, trading is too expensive and small shareholders are losing out. ``London's potential is very, very good,'' said Michael Selby, who teaches finance at the London School of Economics. ``(But) it's not happening yet.'' The Stock Exchange concedes that some criticisms against the system are valid and it is seeking to address them. The Big Bang brought in an electronic automated quotations system that moved trading off the exchange floor and onto securities firms' trading floors. It also opened the securities business to commercial banks and foreign firms. Deregulation allowed more firms to become market makers, who buy and sell shares from their own inventory. Market makers are required to quote prices on the electronic system continuously; buyers and sellers look for the best prices. London's market is based on the United States' NASDAQ electronic over-the-counter system, which began operating in 1971. By comparison, the New York Stock Exchange, the Tokyo Stock Exchange and most of the world's other stock markets are centralized marketplaces where buyers and sellers meet on a trading floor and agree on a price. London's system provides continuous trading and liquidity - or plenty of stock to buy and sell - while the other markets can break down under a flood of sell orders, its proponents say. That contention isn't entirely supported by the facts. During the 1987 stock market crash, London's exchange stayed open, while many other European exchanges buckled under selling pressure. But in the United States, the New York Stock Exchange never closed, which its supporters say saved the world financial system from a meltdown. Meanwhile, many U.S. electronic traders simply abandoned their posts. Since many firms now are owned by publicly-held banks, much more is disclosed about what goes on in the once-secretive London securities industry, and regulation has much improved, said Robin Hutton, director-general of the British Merchant Banking and Securities Houses Association. But there are still problems and complaints. Volume on the exchange shrank to 130 billion shares in 1989 from 150 billion in 1987. Part of the decline is due to a slump in equity trading since the stock market crash that has hindered profits at many firms. One complaint about London is that there aren't enough market makers in each stock to avoid a cartel. And many small stocks don't have market makers, makeing it difficult to trade those shares. London has 23 equity market makers, down from a post-Bang peak of 33, but still more than the pre-deregulation 17. More than 200 of the exchange's over 2,000 domestic stocks had just one or no market makers in September. Another criticism is that some market makers allegedly avoid trading when the market is falling sharply by refusing to answer their phones or taking them off the hook - precisely what happened during the 1987 crash in the United States. Market makers say that if investors can't get through, it's because traders are busy. The firms are running leanly and can't afford to keep extra traders, they say. Critics also said London's spreads between the buying and selling prices are too wide. The average spread for primary stocks in September was 2.43 percent, compared with a pre-crash average of 1.22 percent. The large spread results from London's relatively high trading costs. Market makers must put up their own capital to build up stock inventory and securities houses need expensive computer and telephone systems to trade. Small investors have to pay for a commission and the spread, while institutional investors can find commission-free service. Some firms refuse to handle individual customers because of the expense. Another complaint is that the British paper settlement system, which completes share transactions, is too slow and cumbersome. But the exchange plans to introduce a new electronic settlement system next fall, which could make trading faster and cheaper. Meanwhile, it also has ordered at least two market makers to make competing price quotes on small shares starting in January. The London exchange stands by its system, saying it should be the basis for a pan-European stock market the 12-member European Community wants to create. ``We believe the competing market-making system is the right system,'' said Michael Moore, head of service development at London's exchange. ``And those markets that don't have some electronic form of trading will find it difficult to survive.'' But the exchange's chief executive, Peter Rawlins, said recently the exchange is re-examining its business and infrastructure and would decide by next spring how to move forward.

DOC.HEAD: Unemployed Search for Help to Variety of Troubles
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: ``Surviving unemployment. How to cope with emotional pressures, assess your coping resources. Form a support group.'' The advertisement was enough to catch the eye of Rita Dalpe, an unemployed software engineer who is surviving on temporary work, fewer family vacations and no Christmas gifts this year. ``I'm just looking to hear that somebody is having the same problems I am. I want to hear what other people are doing to keep themselves on an even keel, how they keep from getting discouraged,'' said Dalpe, who also fears her husband may be forced to retire early from cash-strapped Digital Equipment Corp. Dalpe was among scores of people who responded to the ad, reflecting a growing trend nationwide by people out of work who need to talk about the misery of joblessness. ``People are feeling depressed, anxious, angry, irritable,'' said Dr. Eileen Schwartz, the psychologist who initiated the group. The demand for support for the unemployed is increasing. ``We just don't have enough support groups, here in southern California or nationwide,'' said Dr. Paul Lees-Haley, a Los Angeles psychologist who specializes in treating the unemployed. And Right Associates, which offers financial and career counseling and weekly support sessions for laid-off workers, has seen business at its 72 U.S. and Canadian offices increase 32 percent this year, said senior vice president Virginia Lord. ``The reality is: Unemployment is always difficult,'' said Philip Quinn, director of the Massachusetts Bayview Center, which runs employee assistance programs and has been increasingly called on to help firms with layoff procedures. ``But when it goes from 4.9 percent to 7 percent, as it is here, people feel they don't have much of a chance,'' he said. Nationwide, unemployment hit a three-year high of 5.9 percent in November. People reporting to career counselors for job advice are breaking down in tears, said Mary Muir, director of the Massachusetts Department of Employment and Training's regional office in Woburn. ``We are seeing a doubling over last year; 4,100 people are collecting unemployment from our office,'' she said. ``And there are more instances of people who are coming in quite distraught.'' Even the people most of the world looks to for help - mental health workers - are seeking support. The Cambridge-based Family Institute hosts open houses two nights a week for unemployed mental health workers. In California, workers in fields as diverse as the defense industry to real estate are filing more workers' compensation claims and personal injury claims, Lees-Haley said. ``Instead of going home and being depressed, they go to the lawyer and be depressed and file a stress claim,'' he said. Experts say the unemployed complain of short tempers, trouble sleeping and depression. Many people drink and use drugs more heavily, may abuse family or friends or isolate themselves. Dalpe's family has been making sacrifices for the six years she has been without a permanent job, in part so she can receive some sort of counseling. Now, she and her husband are considering selling their home in the Boston suburb of North Reading and moving into a smaller, more affordable condominium. Sometimes, the worries can be overwhelming, she said. ``People of my generation were taught to believe if you got training, it was a pretty sure thing you'd have a job. Obviously, that isn't happening,'' she said. ``White collar unemployment is a new area. Society doesn't know what to do with us.''

DOC.BYLINE: Some Retailers Heartened by Upbeat End to a Down Season
DOC.TEXT: For many of the nation's retailers, the Christmas shopping season was a disappointing casualty of the recession and the Middle East crisis - despite a last-minute burst of business from procrastinating consumers. Some retailers were heartened by a late pickup in their sales. Others, smarting from the poor season, were looking ahead to gloomy times early next year. Sears, Roebuck and Co., the nation's largest retailer, was among those whose sales were hurt this season by consumer worries about the economy and the Middle East. ``We're slightly below expectations,'' Matthew Howard, Sears' senior vice president for marketing, said Monday evening as the Christmas season drew to a close. However, Sears took comfort from its results the last three days of the season, when shoppers responded to a new advertising campaign and a new round of price reductions on a variety of merchandise. ``We're pleased. We felt we got a good balance in all of the businesses,'' Howard said in a telephone interview. The final weekend left Sears' inventories ``in good shape,' he said. Other high-profile retailers reported a last-minute surge in sales, but as in Sears' case, the extra business was not enough to turn the entire season around. ``There was a bit of a rush that was encouraging, but as you know, prior to this weekend it had been pretty sluggish,'' said Suzanne McMillan, senior vice president for marketing at the upscale Saks Fifth Avenue. At Dayton Hudson Corp., Chairman Kenneth Macke was clearly disappointed with the season. When all the receipts are tallied, Dayton Hudson's sales will be unchanged to 1 percent higher than the firm's Christmas 1989 results, Macke said Monday afternoon. ``I'm not feeling very happy,'' he said. Sales that are little changed or up very slightly are considered poor because when the effects of inflation are subtracted, a store's business may be down from year-earlier levels. Consumer prices rose 6.4 percent through the first 11 months of this year, meaning many stores' modest gains were wiped out. Predictions of a poor Christmas season were issued back in August as sales of clothing, furniture, toys and appliances stalled in the wake of the Iraqi invasion of Kuwait. Sales for most retailers did not recover in September, October and November, normally a time when their business accelerates. After the Christmas season kicked off in late November, store traffic and sales generally remained slow until the final weekend. The weather also worked against the retailers this Christmas. In some parts of the Midwest, snow and ice kept shoppers at home, but in many other areas, temperatures in the 50s and 60s curbed sales of winter clothing. Like Sears, many retailers increased or moved up price reductions - especially on coats and other cold-weather wear - in the last few weeks in an effort to draw more shoppers. While the overall industry trend was poor, some retailers ended the season pleased with their results. ``I'm delighted,'' Clark Johnson, chairman of Pier 1 Imports Inc., said Christmas morning. ``We exceeded our expectations ... and clearly it was the best Christmas we ever had.'' He said his stores had a 3 percent increase from 1989's holiday sales. Johnson said the weakening economy actually helped his home furnishings and clothing business as consumers ``traded down'' or bought less expensive gifts this year. ``People that normally bought gifts at higher-end shops came to Pier 1,'' he said. Other retailers also saw evidence of consumers trading down. At Dayton Hudson, business was strongest at the firm's Target discount stores, where sales rose about 2 percent, Macke said. Meanwhile, sales fell at the company's Dayton's, Hudson's and Marshall Field's department stores, which have more expensive merchandise. Jane Arend, a spokeswoman for Wal-Mart Stores Inc., said Monday her company was pleased with its results, but the retailer found it hard to draw hesitant consumers into its stores. Ms. Arend said she could not release any sales figures. The discount retailer has consistently outperformed other storeowners throughout the season. What shoppers bought this season reflected the difficult times. Dayton Hudson had more success with Levi's jeans than designer jeans, and sweatshirts and sweatpants were among the most popular items, Macke said. At Sears, tool sets and portable electric tools sold well. ``When you have a difficult economy, it's a more practical kind of gift people seem to want to give,'' Howard said. Macke said the poor Christmas does not bode well for the first half of 1991. ``If Santa Claus and Christmas can't bring people into the stores, why are they going to be in in January and February?'' he asked. But Johnson thought the last-minute surge was a good sign for his stores. ``We had such tremendous traffic that there'll be nice carryover momentum,'' he said.
